[Question]
if it werent for him i would have been dead by now i cant imagine how horrible he would feel if i did it now im just in an eternal state of depression and cant do anything about it i both love him and hate him for it mostly love but god damn i feel trapped

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I want to offer some guidance and suggestions. It's important to remember that I am not a mental health professional, but I can provide some general support.

1. Validate your emotions: It's completely understandable that you would have conflicting emotions towards the person who has been emotionally abusive in your relationship. It can be difficult to reconcile love and anger towards someone who has hurt you. Acknowledging these complex feelings is an important step.

2. Seek support from trusted individuals: Consider reaching out to friends, family members, or other people in your life who you trust and feel comfortable talking to. Sharing your experiences with someone who cares about you can provide emotional relief and help you gain perspective.

3. Establish boundaries: Setting clear boundaries is crucial in any relationship. Reflect on what behaviors are unacceptable and communicate them assertively with your partner. If they continue to cross those boundaries, it may indicate that seeking therapy could be beneficial for you.

4. Build a support network: Surround yourself with positive influences and individuals who uplift and encourage you. Engage in activities that bring you joy and fulfillment, such as hobbies or joining support groups where you can connect with others who have experienced similar challenges.

5. Focus on self-care: Prioritize taking care of yourself physically, mentally, and emotionally. Engage in activities that promote relaxation and stress reduction, such as exercise, meditation, journaling, or spending time in nature. Make sure to get enough restful sleep, eat nutritious meals, and maintain a routine that provides stability.

6. Educate yourself: Learn more about emotional abuse and its effects. Understanding the dynamics of abuse can empower you to recognize warning signs and seek appropriate help.

7. Consider professional help: While I cannot refer you to a mental health professional directly, there are resources available for you. Look for local helplines or crisis hotlines that can connect you with professionals who specialize in trauma and abuse. They can provide guidance on the best course of action tailored to your specific situation.

Remember, you are not alone in this journey. There is hope for healing and change. Reach out for support, take things at your own pace, and know that there are people who genuinely care about your well-being.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
hi everyone it s my first time posting on this forum i m really in a bad spot wondering if my anxiety ruined my situationship and would love to talk it through with someone if anyone could message me i d really appreciate it here s a bit more color on the situation we were good friend started talking in december hooked up beginning of february got into a disagreement the next weekend at a bar because this girl who he had hooked up with previously wa all over him and it made me visibly very uncomfortable we spend the next week talking every day but not seeing each other i definitely try to initiate a few hangout so doe he but le so and it didn t really work i know he s also talking to other girl a well but continues to tell me that he really like me and just want to keep getting to know me better last saturday we hook up he again tell me how much he like me and that he doesnt want to play game thursday i ask him over snapchat if he want to meet up for st paddy and he doesnt answer we end up at the same bar i make a comment saying ohh i thought you said no game just teasing he get upset and think i m trying to have a feeling talk with him at a bar while he s drunk we flush it out over text the next day and i ask him if he want to hang out this weekend he say we ll see and that he ha some plan already we end up bumping into each other again on saturday this time we talk the whole afternoon but i can tell he s le flirty more withdrawn he s going to a concert so he leaf i tell him later we re all going out to this bar he like and he heart the message this morning i snap him and ask how the concert wa no response obviously i need to leave this man alone at least for a little bit but i feel like back the first time we hooked up he wa so so into me then i ruined it by being jealous at the bar and by continuing to only pursue him i got complete tunnel vision i should have just left him alone and maybe he would have come to me but now i ve put so much pressure on the situation it doesn t help that my roommate who is his friend tell me constantly how much he doesn t actually like me and that he s just a player

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a difficult time right now, and I can understand why you would feel anxious about your situation. It's important to remember that relationships can be complex, and there are often many factors at play.

Firstly, it seems that there was some miscommunication or lack of clarity between you and the guy you've been seeing. When navigating a situationship, open and honest communication is key. It might be helpful to express your feelings and concerns directly with him, allowing both of you to share your perspectives and find common ground.

Additionally, it's natural to have insecurities and fears of losing someone, especially if you've developed strong feelings for them. However, pressuring or pursuing someone too much can push them away. Take a step back and give him the space he needs. Focus on taking care of yourself and engaging in activities that bring you joy and fulfillment. This will not only help you cope with the situation but also create a healthier dynamic between you.

Regarding your roommate's comments about the guy being a player and not actually liking you, it's important to consider their intentions and motivations. Sometimes, friends may have their own biases or agendas. Consider having an open conversation with your roommate to express how their comments make you feel and ask them to be more supportive.

Lastly, working on building your self-esteem and self-confidence can be beneficial. Engaging in self-care activities such as exercise, hobbies, and spending time with positive influences can help boost your overall well-being. Developing a strong sense of self-worth will allow you to approach relationships from a place of security rather than fear.

Remember, every situation is unique, and outcomes can't always be predicted. Focus on being patient, practicing open communication, taking care of yourself, and surrounding yourself with supportive people. These steps can lead to healthier relationship dynamics and increased self-confidence as you navigate your future connections.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

seriously applying for job is hard enough for a stable person but when you have someone like me with no qualification no education no nothing applying for job is downright a soul crushing experience deep down i seriously don t even want the shitty as job anyway but i have to in order to survive then thinking about once i move out living alone in a crappy place working this meaningless job make me internally dieing i genuinely wish i wa never born into this era i don t belong here at all

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I can imagine how challenging and discouraging it must be for you to apply for jobs without any qualifications, education, or experience. It's completely understandable that this process is taking a toll on your mental well-being.

Firstly, I want to acknowledge your courage in reaching out and sharing your feelings. It takes strength to express oneself during such difficult times. While I'm not an expert, I can offer some suggestions that might help alleviate some of the emotional distress you're experiencing.

1. Start by acknowledging your accomplishments: Take some time to reflect on the skills and qualities you possess. Recognize that you have unique strengths and abilities that can contribute to potential employment opportunities. Identify any transferable skills you may have gained from previous experiences, such as volunteer work or personal projects.

2. Explore alternative options: Consider exploring fields or industries that require fewer qualifications or offer training programs. Research companies or organizations that provide entry-level positions or apprenticeships. These opportunities can serve as a stepping stone towards gaining experience and developing professionally.

3. Seek guidance and support: Reach out to local community organizations, career centers, or social enterprises that provide assistance to individuals seeking employment. They often offer resources, workshops, and mentorship programs that can enhance your chances of finding a job.

4. Networking: Build connections within your community by attending job fairs, industry events, or even online communities related to your areas of interest. Engage in conversations with professionals who may provide insights into the industry or even job opportunities. Networking can open doors and create possibilities you might not have considered before.

5. Personal branding and self-promotion: Highlight your personal strengths and interests through a well-crafted resume and cover letter. Emphasize your willingness to learn and adapt, showcasing your determination to succeed. Consider creating a professional profile on platforms like LinkedIn to expand your online presence.

6. Self-care: Prioritize self-care activities that bring you joy and help manage stress. Engage in hobbies, exercise regularly, practice mindfulness or meditation, and maintain a healthy routine. Taking care of your mental and physical well-being is crucial during challenging times.

7. Seek emotional support: Consider reaching out to friends, family, or support groups who can provide a listening ear and understanding. Sometimes, sharing your thoughts and feelings with someone you trust can make a significant difference.

Remember, finding a job can be a challenging process for anyone, and it's completely normal to feel discouraged at times. However, with persistence, patience, and a willingness to learn, you can gradually build your skills and qualifications. Keep reminding yourself that setbacks are temporary, and each experience brings valuable lessons along the way.

Please take these suggestions as general guidance and not professional advice. If you're feeling overwhelmed or believe you need additional support, consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can provide personalized assistance tailored to your specific needs.

Take care of yourself, and know that there is hope for a brighter future ahead.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

 It's understandable that you're feeling depressed and frustrated with your current situation. It can be incredibly challenging when we face difficulties and disappointments, especially if they seem to persist over time. I want you to know that you're not alone in feeling this way, and there are steps you can take to improve your mental well-being.

Firstly, it might be helpful to acknowledge that healing takes time and progress may not always be linear. It's important to set realistic expectations for yourself and recognize that setbacks are a normal part of the journey. By accepting that there will be ups and downs, you can approach each day with a more compassionate mindset.

In addition to managing your expectations, it could be beneficial to explore coping strategies that work best for you. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation, such as hobbies or spending time outdoors, can provide temporary relief from distress. Experimenting with different techniques will help you discover what helps you feel grounded and centered during difficult times.

Another aspect worth considering is seeking support from others. Building a strong network of friends, family members, or even joining support groups can offer a sense of belonging and understanding. Sharing your experiences and feelings with trusted individuals can alleviate some of the emotional burden you're carrying.

Additionally, therapy can be an invaluable resource in navigating these challenging emotions. A therapist can provide a safe space for you to express yourself openly and without judgment. They can also assist you in developing coping mechanisms tailored to your specific needs and circumstances. Remember, therapy is a process, and it may take some time to find the right therapist who resonates with you.

Lastly, self-care plays a crucial role in maintaining mental well-being. Prioritizing activities that nourish your mind, body, and soul can make a significant difference. This might include getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, engaging in regular exercise, practicing mindfulness or meditation, and setting aside time for activities that bring you pleasure.

Remember, the path towards healing is unique for everyone, and it's important to be patient and kind with yourself as you navigate through it. While it may feel overwhelming right now, there are resources available to support you on your journey towards improved mental well-being.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been dealing with a lot of anxiety and insecurity when it comes to making friends and maintaining those relationships. It's understandable that feeling unworthy of friendship can be really tough to handle, especially when you've experienced rejection in the past.

One thing to keep in mind is that building friendships takes time and effort, but it doesn't mean you have to completely change who you are or become someone that feels inauthentic. Being genuine and kind, like you mentioned you try to be, is actually a great starting point for forming connections with others.

When it comes to workplace dynamics, it can be challenging when you feel like the outsider. However, it's important to remember that not all work environments are going to be ideal for building friendships. Sometimes, people form groups based on shared interests or longevity within the company, which might make it harder to fit in right away. But keep putting yourself out there, participating in group activities or conversations, and showing interest in getting to know your colleagues outside of work. Over time, you may find others who share similar interests or values, and those connections could potentially develop into deeper friendships.

Regarding social situations, it's normal to feel nervous about saying or doing something that might make someone dislike you. However, it's important to remind yourself that everyone has their own insecurities and fears of being disliked. Most people are not constantly scrutinizing your every move, waiting for an opportunity to dislike you. If someone does turn on you, it's likely due to their own personal issues rather than just one off-comment from you. It's unfortunate, but sometimes, toxic individuals exist in social circles, and it's best to distance yourself from them if they consistently treat you poorly.

Building self-confidence is crucial in social situations. Practice self-compassion by acknowledging your strengths and positive qualities. Remind yourself that you deserve friendship just as much as anyone else does. Engaging in activities or hobbies that you enjoy and excel at can help boost your confidence and provide opportunities to meet like-minded individuals.

Lastly, don't underestimate the power of small acts of kindness. Showing genuine interest in others, actively listening to them, and finding common ground can lay the foundation for a strong friendship. Building trust takes time, so be patient with yourself and others.

Remember, forming friendships is a process, and it's okay to take things at your own pace. Don't be too hard on yourself if you don't see immediate results. Keep putting yourself out there, participating in activities or events that align with your interests, and remember that rejection is part of the journey. It doesn't define your worth or the value of future relationships.

I hope these suggestions can help you navigate your journey towards building meaningful friendships. Remember, you are not alone in this, and there are people out there who will appreciate and value you for who you are.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

 It sounds like you're going through an incredibly difficult time right now, and I want to assure you that there is hope and support available for you. It's important to remember that everyone's experiences and struggles are valid, regardless of how they perceive their circumstances.

Firstly, please know that reaching out for help takes immense courage. You mentioned feeling close to ending your own life, which is a distressing place to be in. It might provide some solace to know that hotlines such as [insert relevant crisis hotline] exist to offer immediate assistance and emotional support. They can also guide you through this difficult moment and connect you with local resources.

In addition to seeking professional help, there are various coping strategies you can explore to manage overwhelming negative emotions. One approach is to focus on self-care activities that bring you comfort and joy. Engaging in hobbies or activities that you find fulfilling can help distract from distressing thoughts and provide a sense of purpose.

Another strategy is to challenge negative thought patterns by consciously acknowledging and reframing negative thoughts. For example, when you catch yourself thinking, "I'm so disappointed in myself," try replacing it with something more compassionate like, "I'm doing the best I can given the circumstances." This practice takes time and effort but can gradually shift your mindset towards self-compassion.

Additionally, consider reaching out to friends or loved ones who may be understanding and supportive. Sharing your feelings with someone you trust can alleviate the burden you've been carrying alone. If you're concerned about involving family, perhaps you could start by confiding in an acquaintance or a support group where you can remain anonymous.

Lastly, therapy can provide a safe space for exploring your emotions and developing healthier coping mechanisms. A therapist can help you navigate through these difficult emotions, identify underlying causes, and work on building resilience. Remember, therapy is a collaborative process, and it may take time to find the right therapist who resonates with you.

Please don't hesitate to reach out for support. You deserve to be heard and helped.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I want to offer some guidance and suggestions that might help. It's important to remember that everyone's situation is unique, so these suggestions may not be a perfect fit for you, but they might provide some starting points for finding your way forward:

1. Consider reaching out to a trusted adult in your life: While it can feel overwhelming to share what you're going through, talking to someone who cares about you could provide some relief. Think about confiding in a parent, teacher, or mentor figure who has shown empathy and understanding in the past.

2. Explore counseling options: If you don't think you can talk to someone close to you, seeking professional help from a counselor or therapist could be beneficial. They are trained to listen without judgment and can guide you through this difficult period. Some schools or community centers offer free or low-cost counseling services.

3. Take small steps towards self-care: It's understandable that you might struggle with motivation, but focusing on simple self-care activities can make a difference. Try incorporating small habits into your routine, such as getting enough sleep, eating balanced meals, and engaging in activities that bring you joy or relaxation.

4. Reach out to online support communities: Although isolating yourself from friends was a natural response to feeling overwhelmed, consider joining online communities or forums where you can connect with others who may have similar experiences. Sharing stories and advice can provide a sense of belonging and understanding.

5. Explore new hobbies or interests: Engaging in activities that spark your curiosity and passion can help you reconnect with yourself and the world around you. Experiment with different hobbies or join clubs or groups related to your interests. This can also create opportunities for new connections and friendships.

6. Challenge negative thoughts: Recognize that your feelings of unworthiness and loneliness may be influenced by negative thoughts and beliefs about yourself. Try to identify these thoughts and challenge them with more realistic and positive ones. Remember, nobody is perfect, and it's okay to make mistakes or go through difficult times.

7. Seek professional academic support: If you're struggling academically, consider reaching out to a tutor or academic support program at your school. They can provide guidance and help you develop strategies for managing your workload more effectively.

8. Practice self-compassion: Be kind and patient with yourself during this challenging time. Acknowledge that it's okay to not have all the answers or to be going through a tough time. Treat yourself with the same compassion and understanding you would offer a friend in a similar situation.

Remember, these suggestions are just starting points, and it's important to tailor them to your unique circumstances. Taking small steps towards seeking support and engaging in self-care can gradually make a difference. You've already shown resilience by reaching out and sharing some of what you're going through. Keep exploring different options and resources until you find the ones that resonate with you.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i always have these time where i really think about myself in middle school and i get really fuckign sad i wa bullied and treated like shit but i never really admitted to it and wa always in denial about it i never really defended myself or stood up for myself and i wa really quiet and it make me want to slit my throat like i wish i just stood up for myself and defended myself and wasn t such a coward like i can t stop thinking about it and it really fuck up my mood and i always feel so shitty about everything like it s in the past and i can t do anything about it but i can t help but move on and it s constantly in the back of my mind it literally make my blood boil for some reason i have anger issue and when i get treated shitty for no reason especially when i m really quiet and shy it make me so fucking angry like why do u feel the need to pick on someone who s so introverted and clearly not very social like fuck you fuck them all and fuck every person who ever treated me like fucking shit in middle school elemantry school i hope they fucking burn espically this one kid named nick he made my life literal torture and the worst part wa that he wa in every one of my class fuck him and i will always wish nothing but the worst on him

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling upset and frustrated about the way you were treated in middle school. It can be difficult to move on from past experiences, especially when they involved bullying and feeling helpless to defend yourself. The fact that these thoughts are making you feel sad, angry, and impacting your mood is a valid reaction.

One suggestion I have is to consider seeking support from friends, family, or even online communities who may have experienced similar situations. Sharing your feelings and experiences with others who understand what you went through might provide some relief and validation. Additionally, expressing your emotions through creative outlets such as writing or art could also be beneficial.

Another step you could take is practicing self-care and self-compassion. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation can help improve your overall well-being. This might include hobbies, exercise, spending time in nature, or exploring new interests. Remind yourself that you deserve kindness and understanding, just as much as anyone else.

While it's natural to hold resentful feelings towards your past bullies, it's important to remember that dwelling on negative emotions won't change the past. It may be worth exploring forgiveness as a way to release yourself from the burden of carrying around those painful memories. Forgiveness doesn't mean forgetting or excusing the behavior, but rather freeing yourself from the power those experiences hold over you.

Lastly, if these thoughts and emotions continue to significantly impact your daily life and well-being, it may be helpful to seek professional guidance from a mental health expert. They can provide you with additional tools and strategies tailored to your specific needs.

Remember, healing takes time, and it's okay to seek support along the way. You deserve to find peace and move forward from these past experiences.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

so i have bad anxiety and it s been over a year since i ve worked within this past week i ve gotten job interview one i went to but then after i left the place i wa so anxious i developed a migraine and i vomited in my car the second job interviewed i completely ignored and this third one this third interview which i have tomorrow is for a prep cook position but i m considering quitting that too my brain always find some reason to tell me to quit and when i ask for people advice on this job or that job the bad experience discourage me i wa looking forward to trying to be in the kitchen but people tell me it s not worth it it s 0 hour work week little pay and no benefit and plus i don t want to be a manager either i just want to do something for income that i actually kind of enjoy everyone ha something bad to say and that on top of my past horrible work experience i have zero confidence in myself or that any employee or employer i work for will be considerate and relatable and not a total asshole to work with i m a horrible waitress bc my anxiety make me forget order and sometimes forget about a table entirely yet do i want to be in a hot oily kitchen all day and be responsible for people meal it s a tough choice between misery and misery i m depressed about the 9 work week humanity ha created my goal is to grow and sell my own produce and i m a current gardener a it is and my major is agriculture any job for money seems like hell and miserable and i hate having to dedicate myself and my time to a dumb fuck slew of ceo and higher ups who only see you a a number will i ever get over this enough to get myself a job my god this is just miserable day in and day out

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a difficult time with your anxiety and job search. It's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed and discouraged by the negative experiences people have shared with you about various jobs.

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge that finding the right job can be challenging, especially when dealing with anxiety. One suggestion I have is to focus on finding a work environment that aligns with your needs and values. Look for companies or organizations that prioritize work-life balance, offer opportunities for growth, and have a positive company culture. Researching these aspects can help you gain insight into potential employers before accepting any job offers.

Additionally, consider setting realistic expectations for yourself. Instead of searching for a "perfect" job, aim to find one that meets most of your criteria and allows room for growth. Keep in mind that no job will be perfect, but there may be opportunities that are a better fit for you.

Networking can also be a valuable tool in your job search. Reach out to individuals who work in fields or organizations that interest you. They might be able to provide insights into their own experiences and connect you with potential opportunities. Building relationships within the industry can potentially open doors and provide a more personalized perspective on available roles.

In addition to your job search, it's important to prioritize self-care. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and reduce stress can help manage anxiety levels. Consider incorporating relaxation techniques such as deep breathing exercises, mindfulness, or engaging in hobbies that help you unwind.

Lastly, remember that seeking professional support from a mental health therapist could be beneficial. A therapist can provide guidance tailored to your specific situation and help you develop coping strategies to manage anxiety. They can also assist you in exploring any underlying factors contributing to your lack of confidence and negative self-talk.

Remember, finding a job that suits you may take time, but by focusing on finding a supportive work environment, setting realistic expectations, networking, prioritizing self-care, and seeking professional support, you can increase your chances of finding a fulfilling role.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i ve never hated anything this much in my entire life i m stressed out i m so stressed out i m constantly stressed out i m tired of cry every day over school i m tired of being left out by people i thought were my friend everything is so difficult and i want to die i genuinely want to die this is too much it s too much and i m only in freshman year i m only life is only going to get harder from here on and if i m already like this i don t even want to see what s in store for me life suck school suck i want to shove a knife into my head

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now. Feeling stressed and overwhelmed is completely normal, especially when dealing with the pressures of school and relationships. It's important to remember that you're not alone in feeling this way - many people go through similar struggles during their freshman year.

One suggestion I have is to try reaching out to someone you trust, such as a parent or another adult family member, and share what you've been experiencing. Sometimes just talking about our feelings can provide some relief and perspective. They may be able to offer guidance or support as you navigate these challenges.

Additionally, it might be helpful to explore coping strategies that work for you. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and help reduce stress could make a big difference. This might include hobbies, exercise, meditation, or spending time with loved ones. Finding healthy outlets to express your emotions, such as journaling or engaging in creative pursuits, can also be beneficial.

When it comes to feeling left out by friends, it's important to recognize that relationships can be complicated and change over time. Consider reaching out to new people or joining clubs or groups where you can meet others who share similar interests. Building connections based on common hobbies or passions might lead to more fulfilling friendships.

Lastly, keep in mind that while life can indeed be challenging, it's important to focus on small steps forward rather than getting overwhelmed by the bigger picture. Setting achievable goals and celebrating even the smallest accomplishments can help build resilience and motivation.

Remember, there are resources available to you if you ever feel overwhelmed or need additional support. Hotlines like the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline (1-800-273-8255) or crisis text line (text "HOME" to 741741) can provide immediate assistance from trained professionals who are there to listen and support you.

Take care of yourself and remember that things can get better with time and effort. You deserve happiness and success, so don't hesitate to seek help when needed.

i have my mom and grandma but it still feel lonely and i can t talk about my problem with them and my anxiety is kicking me in sometimes i feel like i m overreacting to it i just want to cry and tell people how lonely i m but still i don t want to share my feeling i want to stay strong a much a possible i don t know what i m doing and today is my birthday and no one wish me i m lonely i need someone to know what i feel it s just too lonely

 It can be incredibly difficult to feel lonely and unable to share your feelings with those closest to you. It's understandable that you might want to stay strong and navigate through this challenging time on your own. However, it's important to remember that seeking support is not a sign of weakness but rather an act of courage.

One option you could consider is finding a safe space where you can express yourself freely without fear of judgment. This could be through joining online communities or forums where individuals going through similar experiences come together to share their thoughts and emotions. Engaging with others who understand what you're going through may provide some solace and help alleviate the loneliness you're feeling.

Additionally, writing down your thoughts and feelings in a journal can also be beneficial. It allows you to release pent-up emotions and gain clarity about your experiences. Pouring your heart out onto the pages can serve as a form of catharsis, providing relief and a sense of being heard.

While it may seem daunting, opening up to a trusted friend or acquaintance about how you've been feeling could also lead to surprising results. Sharing your vulnerability might deepen your connection with that person and create new avenues of support. Keep in mind that building meaningful relationships takes time, so take small steps at a pace that feels comfortable for you.

Lastly, exploring self-care practices might contribute positively to your well-being. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and peace, such as hobbies, exercise, or spending time in nature, can help improve your overall mood and reduce anxiety. Taking care of yourself physically, mentally, and emotionally is crucial during times of distress.

Remember, you are not alone in feeling lonely or struggling with anxiety. Reach out and explore different options for support. It's okay to ask for help, and there are people who genuinely care about your well-being.

[Question]
i m f currently on a work trip with a few of my coworkers most of whom i ve known for year but haven t seen in person since covid started i m decently close with one person in particular and the rest i just have a normal professional relationship with last night everyone went out to celebrate a big milestone during the trip and had a great time i wa definitely pretty drunk by the end of the night and getting home is a little hazy but i woke up with good memory of the night before and wasn t concerned that anything had happened anyways no one had texted me this morning and i wasn t sure what the plan for the day wa so i reached out to the coworker i m closer with and asked what she wa up to she said she wa going to breakfast with another person on the trip and that i could come which i agreed to but then she texted and said they were actually leaving right now for breakfast and that we could meet up later this seemed odd to me since we re all in the same hotel and i could have been ready to head out whenever but it felt like she didn t want me to come i think i m reading into it a bit too much but now i m freaking out worried that i did something wrong last night and that s the reason i m not being invited along today i don t really have a track record of doing thing out of character while drunk though so i m just really confused and anxious tldr got drunk with coworkers who i haven t seen in a while and now it feel like no one want to hang out with me

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're feeling anxious and confused after a night of celebrating with your coworkers. It's understandable that you're concerned about not being invited along on activities today, especially since you've been looking forward to spending time with them.

Firstly, take a deep breath and remind yourself that accidents or regrettable actions are not guaranteed just because you were drunk. While it's natural to have some uncertainty due to the hazy memories, try to trust in your own character and past experiences. Accidentally doing something wrong doesn't define who you are as a person.

Given the context you provided, it's possible that your coworkers might have already made plans for breakfast before they invited you. Sometimes people forget to update others or assume they won't want to join. This could explain why it seemed odd when they said they were leaving right away.

Communication is key in situations like these. Instead of assuming the worst, consider reaching out to the coworker you're closest with and expressing your concerns. Let her know that you understand if something happened last night that made her uncomfortable, but reassure her that you value her friendship and would like to clear the air. Honest and open conversations can often lead to resolving misunderstandings.

Additionally, it might be helpful to reflect on your interactions with your coworkers throughout the work trip so far. Are there any specific incidents or comments that could have unintentionally offended someone? Self-reflection can help identify areas where you may need to improve upon, even if it wasn't your intention to hurt or alienate anyone.

While it's important to address any potential issues, remember to take care of yourself too. Engage in self-care activities that bring you joy and help reduce stress. Whether it's going for a walk, reading a book, or practicing mindfulness exercises, prioritizing your well-being will contribute positively to your overall mood and mindset.

Lastly, keep in mind that workplace dynamics can sometimes be complex, and conflicts or awkward situations can arise. However, remember that you were invited on this work trip based on your professional skills and contributions. Focus on the tasks at hand during work hours and maintain a positive attitude. Engaging in office politics or allowing anxiety to consume you will only add unnecessary stress to your experience.

Remember, it's natural to feel anxious in this situation, but try not to jump to conclusions or overthink. Take steps towards resolving any potential conflicts by communicating openly, reflecting on your actions, and focusing on your well-being. By doing so, you'll be better equipped to navigate through these circumstances and maintain a positive work environment.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
im seriously so stuck i developed a horrible case of health anxiety and constantly think something is wrong with my brain or heart i ve been to the er twice now with everything coming back normal i feel bed ridden most day if im up and moving around for too long i feel extremely dizzy due to my tension headache i have high blood pressure and am on medication but i constantly think it s hurting my heart im only year old and i shouldn t be this concerned about my health i m so over feeling this way and every day get worse and worse i feel like i can t do anything but lay down i get sharp pain along my chest due to costochondritis and im always thinking it s the end my breathing is always fine and my heart never beat super rapidly so that make me feel better but the dizziness is unbearable i tried antidepressant and all they did wa make my anxiety worse and my heart beat abnormally fast anytime i stood up my doctor took me off of them and is more focused on my blood pressure im so scared of dying and i m so sick of feeling like this

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really challenging time right now with your health anxiety and the physical symptoms you're experiencing. It's understandable that all of this is overwhelming for you.

Firstly, I want to acknowledge your courage in reaching out for support. That takes strength and shows your willingness to find relief from these distressing thoughts and feelings.

When it comes to health anxiety, it can be incredibly difficult to manage on your own. The fear of something being wrong with our bodies often leads to increased stress and worry, which can exacerbate physical symptoms like dizziness and tension headaches. It's important to remember that your concerns are valid, but also that there may be other factors contributing to your distress.

In situations like yours, it can be helpful to explore different coping strategies and techniques to manage your anxiety. One approach is to focus on grounding techniques, such as deep breathing exercises or mindfulness activities. These techniques can help bring your attention back to the present moment and reduce anxiety levels.

Additionally, cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) can be beneficial in addressing health anxiety. CBT focuses on identifying and challenging unhelpful thoughts and beliefs that contribute to anxiety. By working with a therapist trained in CBT, you can develop skills to reframe negative thinking patterns and learn new ways to cope with your worries.

It's worth mentioning that while medication can sometimes play a role in managing anxiety, it's essential to have a comprehensive treatment plan that includes therapy. Therapy provides an opportunity to address the root causes of your anxiety and equip you with effective coping strategies.

Lastly, finding a support system can make a significant difference. Consider reaching out to friends or loved ones who can offer understanding and encouragement during this challenging time. Sometimes just having someone to talk to can provide immense relief.

Remember, you don't have to face this alone. Seeking professional help from a mental health expert, counselor, or therapist can provide you with the guidance and support you need to navigate through your health anxiety and regain control over your life.

Take care of yourself and don't hesitate to reach out for support. You deserve to feel better.

i plan to commit suicide soon i ve told my bird already i don t think they understand sadly i ve been fighting depression my whole life pretty much i ve tried many time to commit suicide but a i m afraid of pain i didn t go through it thing worsened massively once i lost someone dear to me because of my own action since then i m haunted be it in dream or in reality constantly by them and the result of what i did whilst under psychosis and incredibly suicidal state i began seeking help soon after they left after i realised what i did and it wa really tough at first but i made it for about a year i wish i never met that person it wa a curse i don t really have friend family yes supportive but it doesn t really feel like much i know they d be devastated by my death and so would my bird but every day is the same for me no matter what i try to differentiate and how better it get it s down to the same stuff haunted by those demon that try and make me fall and do what i shouldn t do i ve been told i m meant for great thing but this is all taking forever i m tired of all of this i m tired of living and constantly fighting i just wish to end it all even though it ll mean committing an unforgivable sin edit for the time being i have discarded the thought thank you all for the message and comment

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed and tired of fighting against your depression. It can be incredibly challenging to face each day when it feels like there is no escape from the pain and suffering. However, it's important to remember that there is always hope for improvement and healing.

One suggestion I have is to consider seeking professional help if you haven't already done so. A mental health therapist or counselor can provide you with a safe space to express your thoughts and emotions without judgment. They can also offer guidance and support tailored specifically to your needs. It may take some time to find the right therapist for you, but it could be a valuable step towards finding some relief from your internal struggles.

Additionally, connecting with others who have experienced similar challenges might be helpful. Support groups or online communities can provide an opportunity to share your experiences, listen to others' stories, and gain insights into coping strategies that have worked for them. Sometimes, knowing that you're not alone in your struggles can bring comfort and encouragement.

Engaging in self-care activities can also play a significant role in managing depression. This could include pursuing hobbies or interests that bring you joy, practicing relaxation techniques such as deep breathing or meditation, maintaining a healthy lifestyle through exercise and proper nutrition, and ensuring you get enough restful sleep. While these activities may not directly address the underlying causes of your depression, they can contribute positively to your overall well-being.

Lastly, if you find yourself feeling overwhelmed by those demon-like thoughts and urges, having a safety plan in place can be crucial. This plan should include identifying people you trust and feel comfortable reaching out to when you're in crisis, such as helplines or crisis text services. Removing any means for self-harm from your immediate environment can also be an essential step in ensuring your safety during vulnerable moments.

Remember, recovery takes time, and it's a journey unique to each individual. Be patient with yourself and celebrate small victories along the way. You deserve support and care, and there are resources available to help you navigate through this difficult period.

[Question]
i m not sure if i have anxiety or adhd or im just introverted and procrastinating lol i started biting my nail since i wa a kid i tried hard to get rid of this habit but it not something i can control i put on nail polish usually but once it fall ill start biting them or fixing them with nail clipper a little bit of unsmoothness on my nail will bother me a lot and ill just sit there and keep fixing it for hour straight instead of doing any work literally every 0 min i would find somewhere bothering me on my nail i also overthink a lot it might be influenced by my mom who kept telling me that others might think negatively about me bc of any barely noticeable detail about what i do how i look so now i will just replay some scenario in my head hundred of time feel bad about myself and had to take deep breath say to myself it ok out loud or make some sudden noise to make my mind jump out of that vicious loop recently i feel that my attention span is getting even shorter i will sit down for work and get distracted after min and start watching youtube video for hour i notice myself doing that and i would think maybe i should go back to work but the other part of my mind is like numb and fail to take any action to the point that im only able to focus for a long time under pressure like a day before meeting or exam idk if it is just bad work ethic procrastination introversion or i should get a check up for anxiety adhd like i heard other ppl relate to me on point amp so idk if it just some common problem that i can just work it out either way can anyone give me any advice on whether to get a diagnosis or smth i could do on my own to mitigate these behavior thanks

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you're reaching out and seeking guidance. It can be challenging to determine whether your experiences are related to anxiety, ADHD, or simply being introverted and procrastinating. Let's explore some suggestions that may help you better understand yourself and potentially address these concerns.

1. Reflect on your motivations: Take some time to reflect on what might be driving your behaviors and thoughts. Are there specific triggers or underlying emotions that contribute to your nail-biting habit or overthinking? Understanding the root causes behind your actions can provide valuable insights.

2. Seek support from loved ones: Share your concerns with trusted friends or family members who can offer a different perspective. Sometimes they may notice patterns or behaviors that you haven't been aware of. Their input could shed light on whether they've experienced similar struggles or if your concerns are common among individuals with anxiety or ADHD.

3. Practice mindfulness techniques: Mindfulness exercises can help increase self-awareness and manage unwanted thoughts and behaviors. Try focusing on your breath, grounding yourself in the present moment, and observing your thoughts and feelings without judgment. This practice can empower you to choose how to respond rather than react automatically.

4. Establish routines and habits: Create a structured daily routine that includes regular breaks and designated times for relaxation or enjoyable activities. By incorporating healthy habits like exercise, sufficient sleep, and nutritious meals, you can support your overall well-being.

5. Break tasks into manageable steps: Prioritize your workload by breaking larger tasks into smaller, more achievable steps. This approach can make it easier to focus and avoid feeling overwhelmed. Additionally, consider using productivity techniques such as the Pomodoro Technique (working in short bursts with scheduled breaks) to maintain motivation and reduce distractions.

6. Explore coping strategies: Experiment with different coping strategies to manage stress and anxiety. Some examples include deep breathing exercises, journaling, engaging in hobbies, listening to calming music, or practicing relaxation techniques like progressive muscle relaxation.

7. Challenge negative thoughts: When you catch yourself overthinking or replaying scenarios in your mind, consciously challenge those thoughts by asking yourself if there's evidence supporting them. Replace negative thoughts with more realistic and positive ones. Remember, you have the power to choose how you perceive and respond to situations.

8. Create a supportive environment: Minimize distractions in your workspace and establish boundaries to limit interruptions. Consider using website blockers or app extensions to limit access to distracting websites during designated work periods.

9. Take breaks and engage in self-care: Regularly take short breaks to relax and recharge. Engage in activities that bring you joy and help you unwind, such as going for a walk, reading a book, or practicing mindfulness exercises.

10. Consider seeking professional help: If your concerns persist or significantly impact your daily life, it may be beneficial to consult with a mental health professional who can provide a comprehensive assessment and personalized guidance. They can help determine if anxiety or ADHD is a factor and suggest appropriate treatment options.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. Be patient with yourself as you explore different strategies and approaches. You have already taken an important step by reaching out and seeking guidance. Keep up the effort, and know that positive changes are possible.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i have these bad episode of anxiety that last for day where i m constantly dissociated and whenever i try to sleep i wake up almost every hour with my body completely numb and my vision is like zoomed out and everything is super disoriented and weird i m so tired but i can t sleep and it keep me up all night and i m so exhausted i just want at least one good night rest but i can t even get that i feel like anxiety and dissociation are constantly kicking me around and i can never catch a break in life

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really challenging time with your anxiety and dissociative episodes. It can be incredibly frustrating and exhausting to experience these symptoms, especially when they disrupt your sleep and prevent you from getting the rest you need.

One suggestion I have is to establish a bedtime routine that promotes relaxation and prepares your mind and body for sleep. This could involve engaging in calming activities such as reading a book, taking a warm bath, or practicing deep breathing exercises. Creating a peaceful environment in your bedroom, with dim lighting and comfortable bedding, may also help signal to your brain that it's time to wind down.

Another strategy you might find helpful is practicing mindfulness or grounding techniques during your waking hours. These techniques can assist in managing dissociative symptoms by bringing your focus back to the present moment. Some examples include paying attention to your senses by noticing five things you can see, four things you can touch, three things you can hear, two things you can smell, and one thing you can taste. You can also try using tactile objects, such as a stress ball or a special stone, to anchor yourself in the present.

Additionally, exploring coping mechanisms for stress and anxiety could provide some relief. Engaging in regular physical exercise, finding enjoyable hobbies or activities, and connecting with supportive friends or family members can all contribute to reducing overall stress levels. It's important to prioritize self-care and make time for activities that bring you joy and relaxation.

Lastly, consider keeping a journal to express and process your thoughts and emotions. Writing down your experiences and feelings can serve as a way of unburdening yourself and gaining clarity. Additionally, it may be worth exploring professional support options, such as online mental health communities or forums where individuals share their experiences and offer advice.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, so it might take time to find what works best for you. Be patient with yourself and celebrate small victories along the way. You deserve compassion and care as you navigate this challenging experience.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

1. Self-Compassion: Start by practicing self-compassion. Treat yourself with the same kindness and understanding you would show to a friend. Acknowledge that these negative thoughts about yourself are painful and challenging. Remind yourself that everyone has flaws and makes mistakes, and it doesn't make you any less deserving of love and respect.

2. Challenge Negative Thoughts: Begin questioning the validity of your negative thoughts. Ask yourself if there is evidence supporting these beliefs or if they might be distorted. Consider alternative perspectives or more balanced interpretations of who you are as a person. Remember your strengths, accomplishments, and positive qualities.

3. Seek Support: Reach out to trusted friends or family members who can provide emotional support. Sharing your feelings with someone who cares about you can help alleviate some of the burden. Additionally, consider joining support groups where you can connect with others who have had similar experiences.

4. Engage in Self-Care: Prioritize activities that bring you joy and peace. Engaging in hobbies, exercise, spending time in nature, or practicing mindfulness techniques can help improve your overall well-being and reduce stress.

5. Explore Therapy Options: If you haven't already, consider seeking professional help from a therapist or counselor. They can provide a safe space for you to explore your thoughts and emotions further and guide you in developing coping strategies tailored to your specific needs.

6. Create Structure and Routine: Establishing a daily routine can provide stability and a sense of control. Set achievable goals for yourself and break down larger tasks into smaller, manageable steps. Celebrate your progress along the way, no matter how small.

7. Practice Positive Self-Talk: Replace self-deprecating thoughts with positive affirmations. Challenge negative self-talk by consciously choosing uplifting and empowering statements. Repeat them regularly to rewire your brain towards a more positive mindset.

8. Explore Healthy Coping Mechanisms: Discover healthy ways to cope with stress and difficult emotions. This could include journaling, engaging in creative outlets, listening to music, or exploring new hobbies. Find what works best for you and incorporate it into your routine.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I want to offer some guidance and suggestions that might help. It's important to remember that I am not a mental health professional, but I can provide some general ideas for you to consider.

1. Reach out for support: Consider reaching out to someone you trust, such as a close friend or family member, and let them know what you're going through. Having someone who can listen without judgment and provide emotional support can be incredibly helpful.

2. Seek professional help: If you haven't already, it may be beneficial to connect with a mental health professional. They can assess your situation more thoroughly and recommend appropriate treatment options based on your specific needs. Remember, therapy takes time and finding the right therapist for you is important.

3. Safety plan: Develop a safety plan to help manage any immediate crisis situations. This can involve identifying coping strategies that work for you, removing potential means for self-harm from your environment (such as not driving near bodies of water), and having emergency contacts available if needed.

4. Practice self-care: Engage in activities that bring you joy and relaxation. This could include hobbies, exercise, spending time in nature, or practicing mindfulness and meditation. Taking care of yourself physically and emotionally can help improve your overall well-being.

5. Challenge negative thoughts: Recognize that negative self-talk and discrediting your accomplishments can be common symptoms of depression. Try to identify these negative thoughts when they arise and challenge them by focusing on evidence that contradicts them. Surround yourself with positive affirmations and remind yourself of your strengths and past successes.

6. Build a support system: Reach out to friends, join support groups, or engage in online communities where you can connect with others who may be experiencing similar challenges. Building a network of people who understand and support you can make a big difference.

7. Explore additional treatment options: Alongside therapy, consider exploring other treatment options that might complement your current care. This could include stress-management techniques, holistic approaches, or alternative therapies such as art therapy or music therapy.

8. Take small steps: Break down overwhelming tasks into smaller, manageable goals. By focusing on one step at a time, you can prevent feeling overwhelmed and increase your chances of success. Celebrate each accomplishment along the way, no matter how small.

9. Prioritize self-compassion: Be kind and patient with yourself. Remember that recovery is a journey, and setbacks are common. Practice self-compassion by treating yourself with the same kindness and understanding you would offer a friend going through a difficult time.

10. Distract yourself: When negative thoughts become overwhelming, try engaging in activities that distract your mind. This could include reading, watching movies or TV shows, listening to music, or pursuing new hobbies. Finding healthy outlets for your emotions can be helpful.

Remember, these suggestions are not a substitute for professional help, but they may provide some guidance as you navigate this challenging time. You deserve support and healing, and there is hope that things can improve for you. Keep reaching out and exploring different options until you find the right combination of strategies that work for you.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been going through a challenging time with managing your panic attacks and navigating the process of finding appropriate medication to help alleviate your symptoms. It's understandable that you're feeling frustrated and discouraged by the responses you've received from medical professionals.

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge that seeking help and actively working towards resolving your panic attacks is a positive step. You're taking ownership of your well-being, which is commendable. It can be disheartening when you face obstacles along the way, but please remember that there are options available to you.

Regarding your question about non-controlled medications, there are indeed some medications used for panic disorder that may not be classified as controlled substances. However, it's important to note that I am not a medical professional, and only a healthcare provider can accurately assess your specific situation and determine the most suitable treatment options for you.

In order to find the right medication, it might be helpful to gather more information about your options. You could consider reaching out to a different psychiatrist or mental health clinic to schedule an appointment. When discussing your concerns with them, emphasize that you're looking for non-controlled substance options to manage your panic attacks. This will give them a clear understanding of your preferences and allow them to guide you towards appropriate alternatives.

Additionally, it might be beneficial to explore therapy techniques such as Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) or Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT). These approaches can provide you with tools and strategies to cope with panic attacks and reduce their frequency and intensity. Consider discussing these options with your current therapist or consider seeking out a specialist who focuses on treating panic disorder.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. It's important to have open and honest communication with your healthcare providers so they can tailor their recommendations to fit your needs and preferences.

Lastly, keep in mind that progress takes time, and setbacks can happen along the way. Be patient and kind to yourself throughout this process. Recovery is not linear, but with persistence and the right support system, you can find effective ways to manage your panic attacks and regain control over your life.

Please remember that I'm here to offer guidance and suggestions based on my own life experiences, but it's crucial to consult with a healthcare professional for personalized advice. They will be able to assess your specific situation and provide you with the most accurate recommendations.

 It's clear that you're going through a difficult time, and I want to offer some guidance and suggestions. It's important to remember that everyone's experiences and needs are unique, so take what resonates with you and leave behind what doesn't.

1. Firstly, it seems like you may be dealing with unresolved trauma from past sexual assaults. Working through this trauma can be a complex process, but seeking therapy or counseling could provide you with a safe space to explore these experiences and begin healing. A therapist can help you develop coping strategies and work towards reclaiming your sense of safety and self-worth.

2. Your struggle with borderline personality disorder (BPD) is another aspect to address. BPD can make it challenging to manage emotions and maintain stable relationships. In addition to therapy, educating yourself about BPD can empower you in managing your symptoms effectively. Learning dialectical behavior therapy (DBT) skills, which focus on emotional regulation and interpersonal effectiveness, might also be beneficial.

3. Regarding your strained relationship with your family, it sounds like rejection and emotional neglect have had a significant impact on you. Rebuilding trust and establishing healthy boundaries within familial relationships can take time and effort. Consider seeking therapy specifically focused on family dynamics and communication skills to navigate these challenges effectively.

4. It's evident that you have a strong drive for self-improvement and success. However, it's crucial to practice self-compassion and acknowledge your accomplishments along the way. Setting realistic goals and celebrating small victories can help shift your focus from external validation to internal satisfaction.

5. Your struggle with substance abuse is intertwined with your emotional pain. Seeking treatment for substance abuse can provide you with the tools and support needed to address both issues simultaneously. Recovery programs like Alcoholics Anonymous (AA) or Narcotics Anonymous (NA) offer a supportive community and proven strategies for maintaining sobriety.

6. Lastly, it's essential to create a strong support system around you. Surrounding yourself with people who genuinely care about your well-being can provide the validation and encouragement you seek. Engaging in healthy relationships and building a solid support network can help you feel less alone and more connected.

Remember, this journey takes time, and healing is a process. Be patient with yourself and celebrate the small victories along the way. You have the strength within you to overcome these challenges and create a fulfilling life for yourself.

i m not a big fan of sharing overly personal stuff online so i ll just say that i ll have to take a moderately long plane ride soon a couple week from now i think and every day i have at least one mini panic attack worrying about it there are some minor complication that could happen to me on the flight but nothing particularly harmful or super bad in any sense i m mostly concerned about anxiety claustrophobia and the side effect of that while on the flight this is stressful and feel pointless a i know from past experience i never know how i ll feel until i m there or in this case in the anxiety inducing situation any advice

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It can be challenging to deal with anxiety, especially when it comes to situations like taking a long plane ride. It's great that you're reaching out for support and advice. Here are some suggestions that might help:

1. Preparing for the flight:
- Gather information about the flight and airport beforehand. Knowing what to expect can alleviate some anxiety. Look up details such as the duration of the flight, layout of the plane, and available amenities.
- Create a self-care plan. Pack comfort items like a neck pillow, eye mask, or noise-cancelling headphones. Bring activities to keep yourself occupied during the flight, such as books, puzzles, or a fully charged electronic device with your favorite movies or TV shows.
- Consider discussing your concerns with the airline or airport staff before the flight. They may have additional tips or accommodations to make your journey more comfortable.

2. Managing anxiety during the flight:
- Practice relaxation techniques. Deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or mindfulness meditation can help calm your mind and body. You can find guided exercises online or use smartphone apps specifically designed for anxiety management.
- Distract yourself. Engage in activities that divert your attention away from anxious thoughts. This could include listening to music, reading a book, doing puzzles, or playing games on your phone.
- Challenge negative thoughts. When you notice yourself getting caught up in worry or catastrophic thinking, consciously challenge those thoughts by asking yourself if there is evidence supporting them. Remind yourself that it's natural to feel anxious but reassessing the actual risks can help put things into perspective.
- Focus on the present moment. Instead of fixating on potential future "what-if" scenarios, try to ground yourself in the present. Pay attention to your senses and engage in grounding exercises like noticing five things you can see, four things you can touch, three things you can hear, two things you can smell, and one thing you can taste.

3. Seeking additional support:
- If you have access to the internet during the flight, consider researching virtual therapy options. Some therapists offer online sessions that can provide you with extra support during this time.
- Reach out to friends or family members who may have experienced similar anxieties during flights. Sharing your concerns with someone you trust can be helpful, as they might have practical advice or reassurance to offer.

Remember, everyone's experience with anxiety is unique, so it's important to find strategies that work best for you. If these suggestions don't provide sufficient relief, consider seeking professional help from a mental health expert who can tailor their guidance to your specific needs.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I want to offer some guidance and suggestions. It's important to remember that there is hope and support available for you.

1. Start by acknowledging your feelings: It's understandable that you feel frustrated, hopeless, and burnt out. Take a moment to recognize and validate these emotions within yourself. It can be helpful to write down your thoughts and feelings in a journal or express them through creative outlets such as drawing or painting.

2. Seek professional help: Consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can provide the necessary support and guidance tailored to your specific needs. They can help you navigate through this difficult period and develop coping strategies. Additionally, they may be able to assist you in finding resources that could potentially alleviate some financial burdens, such as sliding scale therapy options or community mental health centers.

3. Prioritize self-care: Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation is crucial during challenging times. Make sure to incorporate self-care practices into your routine, even if it's something as simple as taking a warm bath, practicing deep breathing exercises, or spending time in nature. Taking care of your physical well-being can also have a positive impact on your mental health.

4. Build a support network: Reach out to friends, family members, or even online communities where you feel understood and accepted. Sharing your experiences with others who have gone through similar struggles can provide validation and a sense of belonging. Remember, you don't have to face this alone.

5. Challenge negative thoughts: Recognize that your negative self-image might be distorted due to the overwhelming challenges you're facing. Try to identify irrational thoughts and replace them with more realistic and compassionate ones. For example, instead of thinking "I'm useless," remind yourself that everyone has strengths and talents, even if they're currently hidden.

6. Set small achievable goals: Break down overwhelming tasks into smaller, manageable steps. Celebrate your accomplishments along the way, no matter how small they may seem. This approach can help prevent feeling overwhelmed and increase your sense of accomplishment.

7. Practice stress management techniques: Explore different stress-relief techniques that work for you, such as mindfulness exercises, yoga, or engaging in hobbies that bring you peace and fulfillment. These practices can help reduce anxiety and improve overall well-being.

8. Consider professional cleaning or organizing services: If the burden of cleaning your house feels too overwhelming, you might want to explore affordable local cleaning or organizing services. This can help alleviate some stress and provide a fresh start.

9. Reach out to animal shelters or rescue organizations: If finding a new home for your dog is something you're considering, contact your local animal shelters or rescue organizations. They may be able to assist you in finding a loving family who can provide a safe and caring environment for your pet.

10. Explore job opportunities that accommodate your limitations: Look for remote or flexible job options that align with your skills and interests. Consider part-time or freelance work to start, allowing yourself time to heal and manage your health.

11. Practice self-compassion: Treat yourself with kindness and understanding, just as you would treat a close friend going through a difficult time. Remind yourself that it's okay to ask for help and take breaks when needed.

12. Create a safety plan: In case you experience intense distress or thoughts of self-harm, it can be helpful to have a safety plan in place. This involves identifying people you trust and can reach out to for support, distraction techniques, and making your environment safe. You can find resources online or consult with a mental health professional to create a personalized safety plan.

Remember, these suggestions are not a substitute for professional help, but they can provide some guidance as you navigate through this challenging period. It's important to reach out to a mental health professional who can offer the necessary support and tailor their guidance to your specific needs.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i want doctor assisted suicide no one care a store i wa at last night wa being robbed i didn t hide just went about my business thought it would be best for my family and me if i wa killed the police didn t care they never showed up the loneliness is unbearable

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really difficult time right now. It's understandable that you would feel overwhelmed and hopeless in a situation where you were being robbed and didn't receive any help from the police. Loneliness can definitely intensify those feelings of despair.

Firstly, I want to assure you that there are people who care about you and your well-being. While it may seem like it right now, you are not alone in this world. There are helplines available for individuals experiencing crisis, such as local mental health crisis hotlines or even national ones like the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline in the United States. They have trained professionals ready to listen and offer support 24/7.

Regarding your desire for doctor-assisted suicide, it's important to remember that discussing such extreme measures can be challenging and emotionally draining. However, it is crucial to explore all possible avenues before making any irreversible decisions. Consider reaching out to palliative care organizations or hospice programs in your area, as they might be able to provide information and resources on end-of-life options.

Additionally, seeking therapy could be beneficial for you. A therapist can provide a safe space for you to express your thoughts and emotions without judgment. They can also help you develop coping strategies to manage your feelings of loneliness and despair. You can search for low-cost or sliding-scale therapy options in your community, which may make it more accessible for you.

Engaging in activities that bring you joy and fulfillment can also be helpful. This might involve reconnecting with old friends, joining social groups, or pursuing hobbies that interest you. Sometimes, even simple acts of self-care like practicing mindfulness, engaging in physical exercise, or spending time in nature can improve your overall well-being.

Lastly, consider reaching out to your local law enforcement agency to discuss the incident that occurred. Sharing your experience may help bring about positive changes in their response times or procedures. It's important to feel safe and protected within your community.

Remember, there is hope for healing and relief from the pain you're experiencing. It may take time, but reaching out to the right resources and support systems can make a significant difference in your journey towards finding peace and happiness again.
