[Question]
so i have a mild stutter and i just had an epiphany i ve been letting my stutter control me but i found something amazing out i let my stutter define who i wa a a person instead of an aspect of myself it s so bad that when my parent talk to me like a normal person i d think to myself wow they act like i m normal despite my stutter they see past that and when i would work people would see my name tag and say oh i have a son named my name and i would think he probably doesn t stutter tho i let this define who i wa a a person and i let it really get to me i wa looking at old reddit post from other people asking how people view stutter and most people said they didn t care at all and even found it interesting some even said it wa hot cute made joke sound more natural and a a result more funny not like they found the stutter funny tho and one even said they were turned on by it and someone said something that stuck out to me they pretty much said how you perceive yourself is how others will so if i see myself a weird and anxious i will act that way and be perceived in that way but if i see myself a confident and charismatic and just act like my stutter doesn t bother me and even joke about it then others will perceive me a such this blew my mind a i thought everyone didn t pick up on my stutter at first and just thought i wa super weird but it s just me convincing myself of that so even tho this clicked i still can t just flick the switch off so how do i actually become confident with my stutter it s very mild and is fueled by anxiety so if i can get rid of my anxiety it ll in my opinion make me sound more charismatic and confident so i really wan na figure out how to just own it how do i do this

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you've had this realization about your stutter and how it has been affecting your self-perception. It takes a lot of courage to confront these feelings and work towards change. I can understand how challenging it must be for you to let your stutter define who you are, but remember that you have the power to reframe how you perceive yourself and ultimately how others see you as well.

To start, it might be helpful to explore ways to manage and reduce your anxiety. Anxiety can exacerbate your stutter, making it more noticeable. Finding healthy coping mechanisms or stress-management techniques could be beneficial. This might include deep breathing exercises, mindfulness practices, engaging in physical activities like yoga or sports, or even seeking support from a trusted friend or family member when feeling overwhelmed.

Additionally, practicing self-compassion is crucial throughout this process. Remind yourself that having a stutter does not make you any less worthy or capable than anyone else. Embrace your uniqueness and celebrate your strengths and accomplishments. Building a positive mindset will help build confidence.

Another strategy you can try is gradually exposing yourself to situations that trigger anxiety related to your stutter. Start with small steps, such as ordering food at a restaurant or introducing yourself to someone new. Gradually increase the difficulty level as you become more comfortable. This exposure therapy approach can help desensitize you to speaking situations and build confidence over time.

Furthermore, consider reframing your mindset around your stutter. Instead of viewing it as a negative aspect, recognize the potential positive aspects it may hold. For example, some people find those who stutter to be more genuine and relatable. Remember, others' perceptions may differ from yours, and their opinions shouldn't define your worth.

Lastly, seeking support from a speech therapist or therapist who specializes in anxiety disorders could provide you with additional tools and strategies tailored to your specific needs. They can guide you through developing effective communication techniques, managing anxiety, and building self-confidence.

Remember, change takes time and effort, so be patient with yourself. Celebrate every small step forward and acknowledge the progress you make along the way. You have already taken an important step by recognizing the impact of your stutter on your life and seeking ways to overcome it. Keep believing in yourself, and with time, you will become more confident in how you navigate your stutter.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i m terrible at articulating my thought so apology in advance let me just say up front that no plan ha been made and despite thinking about it so much i don t think i could go through with it this is just a vent piece i guess i feel like such a burden all the time i genuinely only have one real friend left and feel like my roommate co worker hate me i m anti social and awkward i don t make eye contact and i don t talk at all ever i take way too long to text back if i did km i honestly don t think anyone would know until a body wa found or over a month had passed i m just so sick of feeling like an obstacle all the time like i m always in the way or always wrong to think feel a certain way but all of this seems pretty normal i realise it s not a healthy mindset but literally everyone on earth ha trauma everyone ha their own shit they re going through and not only doe it seem like they re handling it a lot better than me but they have real problem i have friend who lost their job over the pandemic i have friend going through break ups grief or whatever and they still manage to practice their hobby and interact with their fellow man but then there s me doing literally fucking nothing all day every day after work and having the ball to feel like shit over it a if it s out of my control i feel weak willed lazy and most of all i feel like the world s biggist egomaniac for writing so much about myself a if it needed to be said thank you for reading my aimless rambling the thought were very intrusive tonight so i just needed to self depricate i guess good night everyone

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed and burdened by your thoughts and emotions. It can be difficult to articulate these feelings, but I want you to know that you're not alone in experiencing them. Many people go through similar struggles and find ways to cope and improve their well-being.

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge that reaching out for support is a positive step towards taking care of your mental health. Sharing your thoughts and concerns with someone who can provide guidance and understanding can make a significant difference. While I'm here to offer support, it's also important to consider seeking professional help from a therapist or counselor who can provide personalized assistance tailored to your specific needs.

Regarding your fear of being a burden, it's common to feel this way when going through difficult times. However, it's essential to remember that true friends and supportive individuals appreciate being there for others during challenging periods. Opening up to them about how you're feeling may strengthen your bond and allow them to better understand how to support you.

Feeling isolated and disconnected from others is another common experience, especially after the pandemic. Social interactions can be daunting, but taking small steps towards reconnecting with others might help alleviate some of these feelings. Consider joining local interest groups or online communities centered around activities or hobbies that interest you. These platforms can provide opportunities to meet like-minded individuals and gradually build new connections.

Additionally, practicing self-compassion is crucial. Remember that everyone has their own unique journey and struggles. Comparing yourself to others is natural, but it can also be unhelpful and detrimental to your well-being. Focus on your progress rather than comparing yourself to others. Celebrate small achievements and milestones along the way, as this can help boost your self-esteem and motivation.

Engaging in activities that bring you joy and fulfillment can also be beneficial. Explore your interests and hobbies, even if they seem insignificant or unproductive at first. Engaging in activities that you enjoy can help improve your mood and overall well-being.

Lastly, it's important to recognize that negative thoughts and feelings are a part of being human. However, seeking professional help can provide you with tools and strategies to manage them more effectively. A therapist can assist you in developing coping mechanisms and exploring underlying issues contributing to your current mindset.

Remember, you have taken an important step by reaching out for support. Keep exploring different avenues of assistance, such as therapy or counseling, to receive personalized guidance tailored to your specific needs. You deserve support and the opportunity to improve your well-being.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now with your period symptoms and feeling unwell. It's completely understandable that you would need to take a sick day in this situation. Your health and well-being should always come first, and it's important to listen to your body when it needs rest and care.

Taking a sick day can be a difficult decision, especially when there are responsibilities to fulfill and others rely on you. However, remember that by taking care of yourself, you'll be better equipped to handle those responsibilities in the long run. Communicating your needs and limitations to your supervisor or colleagues can help them understand your situation and find alternative solutions temporarily.

In terms of feeling guilty or concerned about losing instructional time, it might be helpful to consider discussing this with your supervisor or school administration. They may have insights into how they would like to handle the situation or provide guidance on how to manage your workload more effectively. Remember, they hired you because they value your expertise and contribution, so trust that they will be understanding and supportive during challenging times.

Additionally, finding ways to prioritize self-care can make a significant difference in managing your symptoms. This could include creating a comfortable and warm environment for yourself during break times, even if it means bringing a blanket or extra layers to work. Taking short breaks throughout the day to stretch, breathe deeply, or engage in relaxation techniques might also help alleviate some discomfort.

Lastly, remember that seeking emotional support from friends, family, or loved ones can be beneficial during challenging times. Sharing your concerns and worries with someone who understands and cares about you can provide comfort and reassurance.

Take care of yourself and know that it's okay to prioritize your health and well-being.

Lastly, if you find that these feelings persist or worsen over time, it could be beneficial to seek professional help from a mental health expert. They can provide personalized guidance and support tailored to your specific situation. Remember, there are professionals available who specialize in helping individuals navigate these kinds of challenges, and reaching out to them doesn't mean there's something wrong with you—it simply means you're taking proactive steps towards finding the support you need.

[Question]
hi last year in matheletics i managed to bag at least top 0 but suddenly this year my playing condition have dropped because when i look at the leaderboard every time it make me more anxious and lead to bad performance in the competition now i can not even reach top 000 this ha been making me more stressed and now i even have mixed feeling to never take part in any of these competition even though it thing that i like are there any way to at least calm myself down

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're experiencing a lot of anxiety and stress related to the Matheletics competitions. It's understandable that looking at the leaderboard can be overwhelming and negatively impact your performance. Here are some suggestions to help calm yourself down:

1. Focus on your personal growth: Instead of comparing yourself to others on the leaderboard, try shifting your focus inward. Set realistic goals for yourself and work towards improving your own previous scores or times. Celebrate your own progress rather than solely focusing on your ranking.

2. Practice relaxation techniques: Incorporate relaxation exercises into your daily routine to manage stress and anxiety. Deep breathing exercises, mindfulness meditation, or progressive muscle relaxation can all be helpful tools. Experiment with different techniques to find what works best for you.

3. Challenge negative thoughts: Pay attention to any negative thoughts or self-doubt that arise when you think about participating in the competitions. Replace these thoughts with positive affirmations or realistic statements. Remind yourself that everyone has off days and that it doesn't define your worth or passion for the activity.

4. Break tasks into smaller steps: If the thought of competing feels overwhelming, break it down into smaller, manageable tasks. Focus on mastering one problem or skill at a time instead of pressuring yourself to excel overall. This approach can help alleviate some of the pressure and build confidence.

5. Seek support from others: Consider talking to a trusted friend, family member, or even a coach about how you're feeling. Sharing your concerns with someone who understands and supports you can provide comfort and perspective. They may also have suggestions based on their own experiences.

6. Take breaks and practice self-care: Make sure to prioritize self-care activities outside of Matheletics. Engage in hobbies, spend time with loved ones, exercise regularly, and get enough sleep. Taking breaks from competition-related activities can give your mind and body the rest they need.

7. Explore stress management techniques: Find healthy ways to cope with stress, such as journaling, engaging in creative outlets, or participating in physical activities like yoga or running. Experiment with different stress-management techniques to find what works best for you.

Remember, it's important to be patient with yourself as you navigate these challenges. If your feelings of anxiety and stress persist or worsen, consider seeking support from a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and support tailored to your specific needs.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
so i ve struggled w executive dysfunction for 9 year throughout my year of college there wa not one assignment that i did not do the night before it wa due i studied late ate terribly amp went thru a terrible depression a year after graduating i still have a really hard time doing thing in general i stall before i do anything at all amp it oftentimes lead to me not doing the thing at all also i kind of live my entire life on pause only taking care of myself when i have something planned or to look forward to i left my job that i wa insanely good at bc the commitment amp longevity terrified me why can t i function amp what ha helped u work thru these feeling

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It can be challenging to deal with executive dysfunction, but there are strategies that may help you manage it. One approach is to break tasks into smaller, more manageable steps. This can make them feel less overwhelming and easier to start. Additionally, setting specific deadlines for each step can provide a sense of structure and accountability.

Creating a routine or schedule can also be beneficial. Having a designated time for certain activities can serve as a reminder and reduce procrastination. For example, you could allocate specific times each day for studying or working on assignments. It's important to stick to these schedules consistently to build a sense of habit and routine.

Another helpful technique is to eliminate distractions and create an environment conducive to productivity. This might involve finding a quiet space, minimizing digital distractions by turning off notifications or using website blockers, and removing any clutter or objects that might divert your attention.

Finding motivation can be difficult, so it can be helpful to identify the reasons behind completing tasks. Reflect on how achieving your goals will positively impact your life, such as gaining new skills, improving your career prospects, or alleviating stress. Keeping these motivations in mind can provide the necessary drive to take action.

Breaking tasks into smaller steps, creating a routine, eliminating distractions, and finding personal motivations are just some of the strategies that can assist in overcoming executive dysfunction. However, it's important to remember that everyone is different, and what works for one person may not work for another. It may be beneficial to explore additional techniques or seek support from a professional who can tailor their guidance to your specific needs.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
my memory s fading i m losing weight i don t sleep sex feel hollow i have no motivation to do anything and i frequently think about death i ve been seeing these symptom in myself on and off again for the past few year but never really put them together until now i attributed the weight loss to a study i read stating that just thinking about working out can have benefit despite not actually working out i never really thought of it a a symptom i just saw it a a positive slightly inexplicable development in my life i think i read that i have passive intrusive thought or something like that essentially i think about what it would be like if i wa dead but not about how i would want to die or anything like that the reason for it wa always lost on me i just learned to live with it my sleep issue motivation issue and lack of sexual pleasure have always been present so i never really thought twice about them i thought the memory loss wa due to my rare and infrequent use of recreational psychedelics when i connected all of these together i spent about 0 minute just trying to remember what i had for dinner last night which i found fairly upsetting a up until my teenage year i had an immaculate memory i d still consider myself happy at least to the extent that i ve always known but the symptom are there nevertheless and i m just finding the whole thing quite strange

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling concerned about the symptoms you've been experiencing. It can be helpful to explore these issues further and seek support if needed. Here are some suggestions and guidance for you:

1. Memory loss: Recreational psychedelic use is a possible cause of temporary memory loss, but it's important to note that it typically resolves within a few days to a week. If you've noticed a significant decline in your memory, especially with difficulty recalling events from the past few years, it may be worth considering seeking medical advice.

2. Weight loss: While it's true that thinking about working out can have some benefits, it usually doesn't lead to substantial weight loss on its own. It might be a good idea to consult with a healthcare professional who can assess your overall health and determine if there might be an underlying medical condition causing your weight loss.

3. Sleep issues: Difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep can be quite distressing. Establishing a regular sleep routine and creating a relaxing environment before bed might help improve your sleep quality. Consider avoiding caffeine and electronics close to bedtime, as they can interfere with sleep. If your sleep problems persist, it could be beneficial to consult a sleep specialist or try relaxation techniques like deep breathing or meditation before bed.

4. Lack of sexual pleasure: This can be frustrating and impact your overall well-being. It's important to remember that sexual desire and satisfaction can fluctuate throughout life due to various factors such as stress, relationship dynamics, hormonal changes, and psychological factors. Exploring open and honest communication with your partner about your experiences might help address this issue. Additionally, focusing on self-care activities that promote relaxation and reduce stress could positively influence your sexual experiences.

5. Passive intrusive thoughts: It's common to have occasional thoughts about what it would be like if we weren't here anymore. However, if these thoughts become persistent and distressing, it may be helpful to speak with a mental health professional who can provide guidance and support tailored to your specific needs.

6. Motivation: Loss of motivation can be related to several factors, including depression, anxiety, stress, or other underlying conditions. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and fulfillment could help boost your motivation levels. Additionally, setting realistic goals and breaking them down into smaller, manageable tasks might make it easier to stay motivated.

7. Emotional well-being: You mentioned that you consider yourself happy to the extent that you've always known. It's important to acknowledge and prioritize your emotional well-being. Engaging in self-care activities such as exercise, hobbies, spending time with loved ones, and practicing mindfulness or relaxation techniques can contribute to your overall well-being.

Remember, these suggestions are general in nature, and it's important to consult with a healthcare professional for a comprehensive assessment of your situation. They can provide personalized guidance and support based on your specific needs.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i m starting a new job tomorrow and i m extremely anxious about it i m excited to start this new chapter but i just wish i didn t feel so nauseous right now i ve come really far in overcoming my anxiety but i ve taken everything slowly one baby step at a time this is a huge step the only job i ve had in the past year is instacarting grocery shop amp delivery that i started month ago i did everything at my own pace day a week and maybe a few order a day this job i m starting is hour shift time a week i shouldn t have set myself up for so much but i need to start working towards my career a a dog groomer and this bathing job is an incredible opportunity to do so my living situation is changing soon in that i will need to bring money to the table so i didn t have much of a choice the worst part is i can t actually bathe any dog until i ve learned from the other groomer how to do it which will take time so i worry that the day will go by really slowly because i won t even be doing anything or getting paid until i am ready to start bathing which i don t know how long that will take a friend of mine who work there in the pet store not in the grooming room pulled a lot of string for me with the bos a well my entire family and boyfriend family know i m starting tomorrow and are so happy to see me finally starting to do something meaningful they ve all had a problem with my not working for year because of my anxiety i just feel like not only for my sake but for everyone else s sake i can not screw this up i feel like i m throwing myself into the deep end and hoping i can swim

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 Starting a new job can be both exciting and nerve-wracking, especially when it involves overcoming anxiety and taking on a significant step towards your career goals. It's completely understandable that you're feeling anxious about starting this new chapter in your life.

To help manage your anxiety and make the transition smoother, here are some suggestions:

1. Preparation: Prioritize preparation as much as possible. Take time to familiarize yourself with the company's policies, procedures, and expectations. This knowledge will provide you with confidence and reduce uncertainties on your first day.

2. Practice positive self-talk: Remind yourself that you have come far in overcoming your anxiety and that you are capable of handling this new challenge. Replace negative thoughts with affirmations such as "I can do this" or "I am well-prepared for this job."

3. Deep breathing exercises: Practice deep breathing techniques to help calm your mind and body during moments of heightened anxiety. Focus on taking slow, deep breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth. This simple technique can help alleviate physical symptoms of anxiety.

4. Visualize success: Close your eyes and imagine yourself successfully completing your first day at work. Visualize yourself feeling confident, accomplishing tasks, and receiving positive feedback from colleagues or supervisors. This mental rehearsal can boost your self-assurance and reduce anxiety.

5. Seek support: Share your concerns with someone you trust, such as a close friend or family member. Talking about your worries can provide relief and perspective. Additionally, consider joining support groups or seeking therapy if you feel it would be beneficial for long-term management of your anxiety.

6. Focus on what you can control: Instead of fixating on potential challenges or setbacks, concentrate on what you have control over. You cannot control how fast you learn to bathe dogs, but you can control your effort and dedication to the task. Remind yourself that progress takes time and that you are committed to learning and growing in your new role.

7. Break tasks into smaller steps: If the thought of not being able to bathe dogs until further training feels overwhelming, break down the process into smaller, manageable tasks. Focus on mastering one step at a time rather than pressuring yourself to excel immediately.

8. Take care of your physical well-being: Prioritize self-care by getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, and engaging in regular exercise. Physical well-being can positively impact mental health and overall resilience to stress.

9. Celebrate small victories: Acknowledge and celebrate your achievements along the way, regardless of their size. Recognize the effort you put into learning and growing in your new role. This positive reinforcement can boost your confidence and motivation.

10. Remember that it's okay to ask for help: If you find yourself struggling or feeling overwhelmed, don't hesitate to reach out to your coworkers or supervisor for guidance or support. Asking for help is a sign of strength, and others may be willing to offer assistance or share their own experiences.

Remember, it's natural to feel anxious when starting a new job, especially one that involves taking care of animals. By implementing these strategies and being patient with yourself, you can navigate this transition more smoothly. Keep in mind that everyone has their own learning curve, and your progress will be unique to you.

You have already shown resilience and determination by working towards your career goals despite anxiety. Trust in yourself and the process, and remember that setbacks are a normal part of growth. With time, practice, and support, you will find your footing and build confidence in your new role.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i live at home and i love my parent but i m beginning to spiral after an incident month ago i ve been profoundly depressed and stressed out i wa renting but moved back home to save money while trying to get myself back in order especially because my med stopped working i m an only child and my parent have no friend so now that i m back home all they want to do is constantly talk to me i already have poor sleep a it is but it could be am and my dad will shake me awake to talk about a car or his work day or my mom will come in and talk to me about my finance or why i never talk to her about my mental health one time recently i had been woken up so abruptly i could feel my entire nervous system jolt like i had been struck by lighting even thinking about it make my entire body randomly hurt i never get to be alone anymore i try to get alone time but i never get it for more than a couple hour at an time bc of the sleep deprivation i hallucinate now i hear and see thing i honestly wish somthing would happen to me and it would just all end life s so stressful and the little thing aren t fun anymore i hate myself i hate everything i used to love nothing fun anymore what s the fucking point

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now. Living at home can sometimes be challenging, especially when you feel like your needs aren't being met or understood. It's understandable that the lack of privacy and constant talking from your parents might trigger overwhelming feelings for you.

Firstly, it might be helpful to establish open lines of communication with your parents. Let them know how their presence and conversations affect your sleep and overall well-being. Explaining that you need uninterrupted rest and personal space could help them understand the importance of allowing you to recharge.

Setting boundaries is crucial. You can try designating specific times during the day where you have dedicated "me time." This could be when you take a walk, read a book, listen to music, or engage in any activity that brings you joy and helps you relax. Communicating these boundaries respectfully but assertively could give you the necessary space to unwind and rejuvenate.

Additionally, finding healthy coping mechanisms could make a difference. Engaging in regular physical exercise, practicing mindfulness or deep breathing exercises, and exploring hobbies or interests that bring you happiness may provide some relief from stress and improve your overall mood.

Consider seeking support outside of your immediate family. Connecting with friends, joining support groups, or even reaching out to online communities focused on mental health could offer a safe space to share your experiences and receive guidance from others who may have faced similar challenges.

Lastly, it's important to remember that seeking professional help is always an option. There are therapists and counselors available who specialize in working with young adults and can provide you with the necessary tools and strategies to navigate through this difficult period. They can also assist you in finding ways to cope with your feelings of depression and hopelessness.

Remember, you are not alone in this journey. There are resources available to support you, and it's important to take small steps towards finding the help and understanding you need.

something except talking to people about it i tried it and i regret it especially my parent i m not diagnosed but it s so painfully obvious at least for me i don t even know why i feel this way it s making me unable to do simple shit and everyone around me hate me because of it memory loss is annoying too i swear if this shit is permanent i will fucking lose it

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It can be really challenging to deal with memory loss, and I understand how frustrating it must be for you. It's great that you're reaching out for support and looking for ways to cope with your symptoms. While everyone's experiences are unique, there are some general strategies that might help.

Firstly, it could be beneficial to establish a routine or create reminders to assist you in remembering important tasks or events. This might involve setting alarms on your phone or using a planner to jot down things you need to remember. Breaking down larger tasks into smaller, manageable steps can also make them easier to recall.

Additionally, maintaining a healthy lifestyle can have a positive impact on your cognitive function. Regular exercise, a balanced diet, and sufficient sleep can all contribute to improved brain health. Engaging in activities that stimulate your mind, such as puzzles or learning something new, can also sharpen your memory.

Another approach is to develop coping mechanisms to manage moments of confusion or embarrassment that may arise from your memory loss. One technique is to redirect conversations gently if you find yourself in an uncomfortable situation. You could steer the discussion towards a different topic or ask clarifying questions to buy yourself some time.

 It sounds like you're going through a difficult time right now, and I want to offer some guidance and suggestions. It's important to remember that everyone's experiences and emotions are unique, so these suggestions may not apply to everyone. However, they might be helpful for you:

1. Take small steps: Instead of focusing on the bigger picture or long-term goals, break them down into smaller, manageable tasks. This can make things feel less overwhelming and more achievable. Celebrate each accomplishment along the way, no matter how small.

2. Find meaning in the present moment: While it may feel pointless at times, try to engage in activities that bring you joy or a sense of fulfillment, even if it's just for a short period. Focus on the process rather than the end result. Look for moments where you can find purpose and satisfaction in what you do, whether it's pursuing a hobby, helping others, or simply enjoying nature.

3. Seek support: Consider reaching out to trusted friends, family members, or even online communities who can provide a listening ear or share their own experiences. Sometimes talking about our struggles can alleviate some of the burden we carry. Remember, you don't have to face this alone.

4. Practice self-care: Prioritize taking care of yourself physically, emotionally, and mentally. Make sure you're getting enough sleep, eating well, and engaging in activities that help you relax and recharge. Explore different self-care practices such as mindfulness exercises, journaling, or spending time in nature.

5. Challenge negative thoughts: Notice when negative thoughts arise and challenge their validity. Remind yourself that your current state of mind doesn't define your worth or potential. Practice reframing negative thoughts into more positive or realistic ones. It takes time and effort, but it can help shift your perspective.

6. Seek professional help: If you haven't already, consider consulting with a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and support. They can help you navigate through these difficult emotions and develop coping strategies tailored to your specific needs.

Remember, healing and progress take time. Be patient with yourself and celebrate any positive change, no matter how small it may seem. You deserve support and care as you work through this challenging period in your life.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I want to assure you that there is hope for finding fulfillment and direction in your life. It's understandable that you might feel discouraged, but remember that everyone's journey is unique and progress takes time.

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge the courage it takes to reach out and share your thoughts and feelings. By doing so, you've already taken an important step towards finding support and healing. While I'm not a mental health expert, I can offer some suggestions and guidance that may be helpful to you:

1. Start by seeking professional help: Consider reaching out to a therapist or counselor who specializes in depression and anxiety. They can provide a safe space for you to explore your emotions, work through your challenges, and develop coping strategies tailored to your specific needs.

2. Self-care routines: Establishing a consistent self-care routine can be beneficial in managing depression and anxiety. This could include activities such as practicing mindfulness or meditation, engaging in hobbies or interests that bring you joy, spending time in nature, or even just taking a warm bath. Find what works best for you and make it a priority to incorporate these activities into your routine regularly.

3. Social support: Building a strong support network is crucial. Consider confiding in trusted friends or family members about how you've been feeling. Sometimes, simply talking things through with someone who cares can provide immense relief. Additionally, joining support groups or online communities focused on mental health can connect you with individuals who understand your struggles and can offer empathy and advice based on their own experiences.

4. Challenge negative thoughts: Depression often fuels negative thinking patterns that perpetuate feelings of worthlessness and hopelessness. Start questioning these thoughts and actively challenge them by looking for evidence that contradicts them. For example, if you find yourself thinking, "I've never really succeeded in life," remind yourself of any accomplishments, no matter how small they may seem.

5. Set realistic goals: Break down your larger aspirations into smaller, achievable goals. By setting realistic expectations for yourself, you can build a sense of accomplishment and motivation. Celebrate each step forward, regardless of their size, as it will help reinforce positive feelings and give you a sense of progress.

6. Engage in meaningful activities: Explore activities that bring meaning and purpose to your life. This could involve volunteering for a cause you care about, pursuing creative endeavors, or finding a part-time job that aligns with your interests. Engaging in activities that have a positive impact on others can often lead to a sense of fulfillment and satisfaction.

7. Practice self-compassion: Be kind and understanding towards yourself. Remember that healing is a journey, and setbacks are normal. Treat yourself with the same compassion and patience you would offer a friend going through a difficult time.

8. Seek professional guidance: Consider reaching out to a career counselor or coach who can help you explore your strengths, interests, and potential career paths. They can provide valuable insights and support as you navigate the process of finding a fulfilling career that aligns with your passions and goals.

Remember, this is just the beginning. It may take time to find the right therapist or counselor who resonates with you, so don't be discouraged if the first one you meet isn't a perfect fit. Keep reaching out until you find someone who can provide the support and guidance you need.

Lastly, it's important to note that I am not a mental health professional, and these suggestions are based on my personal experience and observations. It's crucial to consult with a qualified therapist or counselor for personalized advice and support tailored to your specific needs.

Take care of yourself, reach out for help, and know that there is hope for a brighter future ahead.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
my other alt account wa deleted so i m posting here today i had a mental breakdown on the basis of what i feel are good thing in my life disappearing inexplicably oftentimes whenever i attempt interaction with aforementioned good thing the last straw wa today over a fairly trivial issue but i broke down because of so many thing that had happened recently in my past that i wa unable to shrug off my life is fairly good and i am very lucky to be living in a household full of opportunity however it feel a though whenever i try to fully indulge in what s provided to me whether it be by my hand or anothers it s normally gone in no time flat about the call i wa in the middle of my breakdown and tried to take the rational course of action calling the hotline because i desperately needed to talk with somebody only to vent my frustration and promptly be hung up on by the person on the other end of the line i tried calling twice more ok case i hung up on then by accident but wa almost immediately disconnected and the last time wasn t able to be connected with anyone fuck what if i were actually about to commit suicide and just wanted someone to talk with only to find out that they didn t care about my problem either it anger me just typing this i m sick of living this way i don t think suicide is the answer but i really just need someone to talk with about my frustration thanks for reading and hopefully your day is better than mine

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a difficult time right now. It can be incredibly frustrating and disheartening when things that seem good in our lives inexplicably disappear, especially when we're unable to shrug off those losses. It's understandable that you had a mental breakdown over a trivial issue due to the accumulation of recent events.

The experience you had with the hotline must have been really upsetting. Feeling hung up on and disconnected can make anyone feel even more frustrated and unimportant. It's not fair to think that they don't care about your problem either; sometimes calls get dropped accidentally, and it might just be a coincidence. However, I can imagine how distressing it must have felt for you at that moment.

You mentioned that you don't think suicide is the answer, which is a positive step. It shows that you recognize there might be other ways to cope with these feelings. Talking with someone who can provide emotional support could be immensely helpful in navigating through this difficult period. While I'm not an expert, there are helplines available specifically for individuals experiencing crisis or needing someone to talk to. They have trained professionals who can listen to your concerns and offer guidance. You might consider reaching out to one of these helplines again, sharing your previous experience, and expressing your need for support.

In addition to seeking professional help, it could also be beneficial to explore healthy coping mechanisms that work for you. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation, such as hobbies, exercise, or creative outlets, can serve as distractions from negative thoughts and emotions. Developing a self-care routine that includes regular exercise, sufficient sleep, and a balanced diet can contribute positively to your overall well-being.

Journaling your thoughts and emotions might also be worth considering. Writing down your experiences, frustrations, and even moments of gratitude can provide a sense of release and clarity. Additionally, confiding in a trusted friend or family member about what you're going through can help alleviate some of the burdens you may be carrying.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. It's important to explore different strategies and find what resonates with you personally. While these suggestions can be helpful, it's always a good idea to consult with a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and support tailored to your specific needs.

I hope you find the help and support that you need, and I encourage you to keep reaching out until you do. You deserve to have someone who will listen and offer guidance during this challenging time. Take care of yourself, and don't hesitate to seek professional help if you haven't already done so.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i already called in yesterday for work i wa up all night laying here just awake counting down the hour to work wa so exhausted by the time work came around that i called in and even then i couldn t sleep it s now 0 pm and i ve gotten under an hour of sleep in the last 0 hr i m starting to worry a bit this month ha been so hard for me i literally almost walked into traffic on the way to work last week been cry so much i m so alone and it really scare me because i m going through all of this by myself

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been experiencing a lot of stress and anxiety lately, which has been affecting your sleep and overall well-being. It's understandable that you're feeling worried about this situation.

One suggestion I have is to try incorporating some relaxation techniques into your routine before bed. Deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or guided imagery can help calm your mind and prepare your body for sleep. You might also consider creating a relaxing environment in your bedroom by reducing noise, dimming the lights, and keeping the room at a comfortable temperature.

Additionally, it could be helpful to establish a consistent sleep schedule. Going to bed and waking up at the same time every day, even on weekends, can regulate your body's internal clock and improve the quality of your sleep. Creating a bedtime routine, such as reading a book or taking a warm bath, can signal to your brain that it's time to wind down and prepare for rest.

Another strategy you might explore is finding healthy outlets for your emotions during the day. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and provide a sense of fulfillment can help reduce stress levels. This could include hobbies, exercise, spending time with loved ones, or pursuing creative endeavors. Taking breaks throughout the day to engage in these activities can give you moments of respite and replenish your energy.

Moreover, reaching out for support from others can make a significant difference. Sharing your experiences and feelings with trusted friends or family members can offer comfort and perspective. They may not have all the answers, but they can provide a listening ear and emotional support. Sometimes, simply knowing that we're not alone in our struggles can be incredibly reassuring.

Lastly, if you find that these strategies aren't bringing relief or if your symptoms worsen, it may be beneficial to seek professional help from a mental health expert. They can assess your situation more comprehensively and tailor interventions specifically to your needs. Remember, there are resources available to you, and you don't have to face this alone.

Take care of yourself and remember that there is hope for improvement.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i m a frequent poster here i ve struggled all my life with these feeling thing seemed like they were getting better i wa genuinely happy and then it got taken away again i live in shitty section housing i wa kicked out several year ago and i ve been struggling to stay afloat since my mother and i recently discussed me moving back home which wa le than ideal she bought a condo and offered it to me she even suggested i get a roommate i wa overjoyed my so could move in my best friend could move it it seemed wonderful and then once i already signed the paper to move out in two month my mother told me to stop looking for a roommate she ha been considering moving into the larger bedroom and taking my kid sister with her leaving me alone in the smaller bedroom with no support and i have no place to argue against this she bought me a new car a an early birthday gift she s paying for me to go through school i m currently struggling to keep my grade up and she s rightfully angry about it my apartment is messy and she s mad about that too rightfully so i am going to lose my privacy and be stuck in the tiny condo with her without support from my so and my best friend my mother is very controlling so i know i won t be able to play video game or talk to my friend in peace it ll just be lecturing do your homework look for a better job etc etc i don t have the motivation for either i barely have motivation to go to my current job she doesn t get that i m so incredibly depressed and suicidal every single fucking day i just got rejected for a better job and now on top of all that i ll be stuck in a confined space with her with no freedom again and i ll probably become babysitter again for the child i pretty much raised for her it s not fair

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now. It can be incredibly challenging to have your living situation change unexpectedly, especially when it affects your independence and support system. It's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed, frustrated, and depressed.

In situations like these, it can be helpful to take some time to process your emotions and explore potential options for moving forward. Here are a few suggestions that might assist you in navigating this difficult situation:

1. Communication: Consider having an open and honest conversation with your mother about how you're feeling. Share your concerns regarding the loss of privacy, lack of support from your SO and best friend, and the impact it may have on your mental health. Try to find common ground or compromises that could benefit both of you.

2. Seek support: Reach out to friends, other family members, or even online communities who may provide emotional support during this challenging period. Having someone to talk to and share your feelings with can make a significant difference in managing stress and improving overall well-being.

3. Self-care: Engage in activities that bring you joy and help alleviate stress. This could include hobbies, exercise, meditation, or any other self-care practices that promote relaxation and positive mental health. Taking care of yourself will be crucial during this time.

4. Establish boundaries: If you decide to move back in with your mother, it would be beneficial to establish clear boundaries early on. Discuss specific areas of concern, such as personal space, privacy, and household responsibilities, to ensure that both parties are aware of each other's expectations.

5. Prioritize your mental health: Consider seeking professional help by reaching out to a therapist or counselor who specializes in working with young adults and family dynamics. They can provide guidance and support tailored to your unique circumstances.

6. Explore resources: Look into local community resources that might be available to you, such as career counseling services, financial assistance programs, or support groups. These resources can often provide guidance and assistance during challenging times.

Remember, it's important to take things one step at a time and acknowledge that you're doing the best you can under difficult circumstances. Be patient with yourself and allow for flexibility as you navigate this new living arrangement. You have the strength within you to overcome these challenges and find ways to create a fulfilling life for yourself.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i m tired depressed and can t go through this alone anymore i haven t been kind to myself i ve taken a pill because i don t want to stay awake even though it s really early can you leave me a comment so that i won t wake up to zero notification maybe something to make me get out of the bed a little easier

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling tired, depressed, and overwhelmed right now. It takes a lot of strength to reach out for support. Remember that you don't have to go through this alone – there are people who care about your well-being.

Taking a pill to help you sleep can be dangerous, especially if it wasn't prescribed by a healthcare professional. If you're struggling to stay awake, it might be helpful to create a relaxing bedtime routine instead. Consider incorporating activities like reading a book, taking a warm bath, or practicing deep breathing exercises before bed. These rituals can signal to your body that it's time to rest and may make falling asleep easier.

In addition to improving your sleep habits, it could also be beneficial to establish a morning routine that encourages positivity and self-care. For example, setting aside time each day for activities you enjoy – such as listening to uplifting music, journaling, or engaging in hobbies – can provide motivation to get out of bed. Prioritizing self-care in the mornings can set a positive tone for the rest of the day.

While leaving comments on posts may offer temporary relief, it's important to explore more sustainable sources of support. Building a strong support network is crucial when facing difficult times. Reach out to trusted friends or family members who can lend an ear or provide emotional support. Sometimes just having someone to talk to can make a significant difference.

Additionally, consider seeking professional help from mental health experts. They can provide guidance tailored specifically to your needs and circumstances. Online resources, support groups, or helplines might also be available in your area – researching these options could lead you to valuable resources and connections.

Remember, recovery is a journey, and it's okay to ask for help along the way. You deserve compassion and understanding as you navigate through this challenging time. Keep reaching out and exploring different avenues of support until you find what works best for you.

hi all i m f i ve had very bad anxiety disorder since 0 0 when my uncle passed away the following year i started taking medication and while it help it s not a cure all both my parent passed under different circumstance in october and it s wrecked my emotion i try to do the best i can but sometimes it s just a mess i m out of town right now and i feel so outside of my comfort zone i know i m safe but my stomach is in knot and sorry tmi i haven t left the bathroom much doe anyone have any advice is there anything i can do to calm myself or center myself thank you in advance

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It can be incredibly challenging to navigate life when you're dealing with anxiety disorder, especially during times of intense emotional distress like losing loved ones. It's understandable that your current state feels overwhelming, but there are steps you can take to help manage your anxiety and find some relief.

Firstly, it might be helpful to focus on self-care practices. Engaging in activities that promote relaxation and stress reduction can have a positive impact on your overall well-being. You could try deep breathing exercises or mindfulness techniques, which can help calm both the mind and body. Additionally, incorporating regular physical exercise into your routine can release endorphins and reduce anxiety levels.

In addition to these self-care practices, seeking support from others who understand what you're going through can also be beneficial. Consider reaching out to online communities or forums where individuals dealing with similar challenges can offer empathy and advice based on their own experiences. Sometimes just knowing that you're not alone in your struggles can provide comfort and encouragement.

Another suggestion is to explore different grounding techniques when you feel overwhelmed by anxiety. These techniques involve focusing your attention on the present moment through sensory experiences. For example, you could try using your senses to describe specific objects around you or engage in soothing tactile activities such as playing with putty or rubbing a smooth stone.

Lastly, remember that it's okay to ask for professional help if you need it. If you haven't already, consider finding a mental health professional who specializes in anxiety disorders. They can provide guidance tailored to your unique situation and potentially suggest additional coping strategies or therapies that may benefit you.

Remember, managing anxiety is a journey, and it takes time to find what works best for you. Be patient with yourself and celebrate small victories along the way. You deserve compassion and support as you navigate this difficult period of your life.

These lifestyle changes can positively impact your cardiovascular system and potentially reduce the risk of developing heart disease.

Lastly, if you find it challenging to overcome the fear or apprehension associated with visiting a doctor, confide in a trusted friend or family member who can accompany you during the appointment. Having someone by your side can provide emotional support and help alleviate any anxiety you may feel.

Lastly, don't forget about the power of resilience. It's natural to face setbacks along the way, but remember that failure is a part of growth. Learn from your experiences, adapt, and keep moving forward. Surround yourself with positive influences and people who uplift you.

Additionally, identifying designated safe places or people nearby whom you can approach if needed might also be beneficial.

Next time you're in a similar situation, consider using safety apps or emergency services features on your phone that can provide immediate assistance. These apps often include GPS tracking, allowing authorities or trusted contacts to locate you quickly.

It may also be helpful to take self-defense classes or attend workshops that teach strategies for handling difficult situations. Learning assertiveness techniques and setting boundaries can empower you to navigate potentially dangerous encounters.

Finally, remember the importance of self-care. Traumatic experiences can leave us feeling vulnerable and on edge. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation, such as exercise, hobbies, or spending time with loved ones, can help alleviate stress and promote a sense of well-being.

While these suggestions won't erase the pain and fear you're currently experiencing, they may offer some guidance moving forward. Your safety and emotional well-being are essential, and it's important to prioritize both as you navigate challenging situations.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's really tough to hear what you're going through, and I want you to know that reaching out is a brave step. Dealing with depression can be incredibly challenging, especially when you feel isolated in a small town with limited resources. Having suicidal thoughts can be terrifying, and it's important to take them seriously. It's positive that you haven't acted on them recently, but it's still important to have a plan in place to ensure your safety. One suggestion could be to identify someone you trust, such as a family member or friend, who you can reach out to when you're feeling overwhelmed. Opening up to them about what you're experiencing might provide some relief and they may be able to offer support or encouragement.

Additionally, finding healthy coping mechanisms that work for you can make a difference. Engaging in activities that bring you joy or provide a sense of accomplishment can help distract from negative thoughts. This could include hobbies, exercise, creative outlets, or even volunteering. Exploring these activities might help you find something that brings positivity into your life and helps alleviate some of the emotional burden.

While it may seem difficult to navigate the mental health system in your area, there are often local crisis hotlines or helplines available. These services can connect you with trained professionals who can provide immediate assistance and guidance. They may also be able to direct you to additional resources specific to your location.

Lastly, remember that seeking professional help is always an option worth considering. While I'm not able to refer you to a mental health expert, there are professionals out there who specialize in treating depression and can provide the support you need. If you feel ready to take that step, reaching out to a therapist or counselor in your area might be beneficial.

i don t feel like myself anymore and i don t think i can be fixed not a day go by where i wish i didn t wake up again i don t know what s wrong and i ve been trying so hard to be better i just can t do it anymore i m so sorry

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I want to offer some guidance and suggestions that might help. It's important to remember that everyone's journey is unique, but there are steps you can take towards feeling better.

Firstly, it's important to reach out for support from people who care about you. Sharing your feelings with someone you trust, such as a close friend or family member, can provide an outlet for emotional release and understanding. They may also be able to provide practical assistance or suggest resources that could be helpful.

Additionally, consider exploring different coping strategies that resonate with you. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and fulfillment, such as hobbies, exercise, or creative outlets, can have a positive impact on your mental well-being. Experimenting with relaxation techniques like deep breathing exercises, meditation, or mindfulness might also be worth trying.

Another suggestion is to establish a routine that incorporates self-care practices. This could include maintaining regular sleep patterns, eating nutritious meals, and engaging in activities that promote relaxation and stress reduction. Taking care of your physical health can positively influence your mental well-being.

In addition to these suggestions, it might be beneficial to seek professional help. There are various mental health resources available, including hotlines, crisis centers, and support groups. These organizations can connect you with trained professionals who can provide guidance tailored to your specific needs. Remember, reaching out for help is not a sign of weakness; rather, it demonstrates strength and a willingness to take steps towards healing.

Lastly, keep in mind that recovery is a process and setbacks are common. Be patient and kind to yourself throughout this journey. Celebrate small victories along the way and acknowledge the progress you make, no matter how small it may seem.

Remember, you don't have to face this alone. There is hope for improvement, and with the right support and strategies, things can get better.

im and mo postpartum i don t know if i have ppocd but the intrusive thought are becoming unbearable my baby is healthy and for the most part happy a lot of the time i feel like a shitty mom because i work full time while my boyfriend is at home with the baby and when i get home im too exhausted to clean house or play with my baby i carry so much guilt about other people watching my son on my day off so i can get thing done because i m his mom and i should be able to take care of him and everything else myself tonight he wa losing his sh t bc he wa overtired his screaming made me feel like i wanted to hurt him or myself i would never hurt him but the thought get so loud i can t seem to escape them i wa in a psych hospital last month but it didn t help at all these thought are a constant sometimes i feel like having a baby wa the wrong choice and i ruined my life and the only way to fix my issue is to end it i just feel so alone

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I want to offer some guidance and suggestions. First of all, it's important to remember that being a new parent can be overwhelming, and it's normal to feel exhausted and guilty about not being able to do everything yourself. It's great that you have a supportive partner who is at home with your baby while you work full time.

The intrusive thoughts you mentioned can be really distressing, but it doesn't necessarily mean you have ppocd. It's common for parents to have thoughts about harming their children due to stress or anxiety, and it doesn't mean they would actually act on those thoughts. However, if these thoughts are causing you significant distress and affecting your ability to function, it might be helpful to seek professional help from a mental health therapist or counselor. They can provide strategies to manage and cope with these thoughts effectively.

Regarding feeling like a shitty mom, it's important to remember that being a good parent isn't about doing everything perfectly or being constantly available for your child. It's about providing love, care, and a safe environment for your child to grow up in. You're working hard to support your family, and that is a valuable contribution. Remember to give yourself credit for what you are able to provide for your child.

Feeling overwhelmed and exhausted is common among new parents, especially when juggling work and childcare. It's important to prioritize self-care and ask for support when needed. Consider reaching out to friends, family members, or even online communities for emotional support. Taking breaks, engaging in activities that bring you joy, and practicing relaxation techniques can also help alleviate stress.

Lastly, if you're feeling suicidal, please know that there is help available to you. Reach out to a helpline or crisis hotline in your area for immediate support. They can provide guidance on how to keep yourself safe during difficult times. Remember, you don't have to go through this alone. There are people who care about your well-being and want to support you.

Take care of yourself, reach out for support, and remember that it's okay to ask for help. You deserve to find peace and happiness as a parent.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

also i can t even look nobody in the eye because of it wtf do i do it s ruining the relationship i have with my family and parent it s just pissing me tf off i went to get a haircut today but walked tf out because i wa too anxious and my anxiety wa high so when i walked in i sat all the way in the back so my barber and other people wouldn t see me because of my dumbass anxiety but how else wa i gon na get a cut if he couldn t see me right so like i said i just walked tf out with my head down n cried when i got home

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're dealing with a lot of frustration and anxiety in your daily life, especially when it comes to looking people in the eye and managing social situations. It's understandable that this is causing distress and impacting your relationships with your family and parents.

One suggestion I have is to consider practicing gradual exposure to situations that make you anxious about eye contact. Start by setting small goals for yourself, such as trying to maintain eye contact for a few seconds at a time while speaking to someone you trust. As you become more comfortable, gradually increase the duration or try it in different settings. This can help desensitize you to the fear and reduce anxiety over time.

Another technique that might be helpful is called cognitive restructuring. It involves identifying and challenging negative thoughts or beliefs that contribute to your anxiety. For example, if you find yourself thinking, "Everyone will judge me if I look them in the eye," you could challenge that thought by reminding yourself that most people are focused on themselves rather than judging others. By reframing negative thoughts, you can develop a more realistic and positive mindset.

Additionally, deep breathing exercises can be beneficial in managing anxiety symptoms. When you notice yourself becoming overwhelmed or anxious, take slow, deep breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth. Focusing on your breath can help calm your nervous system and bring your attention back to the present moment.

Engaging in regular physical exercise can also have a positive impact on anxiety levels. Exercise releases endorphins, which are natural mood boosters. Find an activity that you enjoy, whether it's going for a walk, dancing, or playing a sport, and incorporate it into your routine. Aim for at least 30 minutes of moderate-intensity exercise most days of the week.

Lastly, seeking support from a trusted friend or loved one can be valuable. Talking about your struggles with someone who understands and cares about you can provide comfort and perspective. They may even offer suggestions or insights based on their own experiences.

Remember, overcoming anxiety takes time and effort. Be patient with yourself and celebrate small victories along the way. If you find that these strategies aren't providing enough relief, it may be beneficial to seek professional help from a mental health expert who can provide personalized guidance and support tailored to your specific needs.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

If you're comfortable doing so, consider reaching out to your therapist and discussing how you're feeling. They can provide a safe space for you to express yourself without judgment or pressure.

In addition to therapy, there are other strategies you can explore to manage your emotions and reduce the risk of self-harm. One approach is developing a personalized safety plan. This involves identifying warning signs, creating a list of coping techniques, reaching out to supportive individuals, and knowing which emergency services to contact if needed. Having a plan in place can provide a sense of preparedness and security.

Exploring healthy coping mechanisms may also be beneficial. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation, such as hobbies, exercise, or spending time in nature, can help alleviate stress and improve overall well-being. Additionally, connecting with others who understand your struggles can be comforting. Consider joining support groups or online communities where you can share experiences and receive encouragement from individuals who have faced similar challenges.

Lastly, take care of yourself by practicing self-compassion. Remember that healing takes time, and setbacks are a part of the process. Be patient with yourself and celebrate small victories along the way. Surround yourself with positive influences and engage in self-care activities that promote mental well-being.

Please keep in mind that my suggestions are not a substitute for professional help. If you need immediate assistance, please contact a helpline specific to your country or region. They can provide you with the necessary support and guidance.

 It's completely understandable that you're feeling this way, and I want to assure you that it's okay. It's natural to have a range of emotions and experience ups and downs. While it may feel like you don't feel much at times, remember that emotions are complex and can sometimes be difficult to put into words.

Feeling bad about not feeling much is a common reaction, but it's important to remind yourself that experiencing a lack of emotion doesn't make you any less deserving or valuable as a person. Emotions come and go, and it's alright to give yourself permission to feel whatever arises without judgment.

Wishing you were better for me is a compassionate sentiment, but remember that everyone has their own unique journey and struggles. It's not solely your responsibility to make things better. We can support each other and work together, but ultimately, we all have limitations and imperfections.

Crying and feeling overwhelmed are natural responses to various situations. Sometimes, tears can provide relief or release pent-up emotions. It's important to allow yourself to feel these emotions fully when they arise rather than suppressing them. If you find yourself crying more than you'd like, it might be helpful to explore coping strategies or seek additional support.

Feeling a lot of emotion can also be overwhelming at times. It might help to remind yourself that experiencing intense emotions doesn't necessarily mean something is wrong with you. Emotions can be intense and overwhelming for everyone from time to time. However, if this intensity persists or significantly impacts your daily life, it could be beneficial to seek guidance from a mental health professional who can offer personalized support.

Remember, I'm here to listen and support you. You're not alone in this journey, and together we can navigate through these emotions.

dutifully working a job that doesn t care about my humanity training people to replace me dutifully caring for a pet that make my mental health worse training them a i stress cry dutifully filling out tax for my dead parent emailing lawyer because my sibling won t fulfill their legal obligation dutifully attending counseling with my spouse actively listening to being told my want and need are wrong dutifully laying in bed quietly so a not do disturb anyone else staring at the ceiling through insomnia and intrusive thought understanding that i don t exist i am just a tool for everyone else this is my duty

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're dealing with a lot of stress and feeling overwhelmed by the various responsibilities and expectations placed on you. It's important to remember that your feelings and needs are valid, and it's okay to prioritize your own well-being.

Firstly, regarding your job, it can be challenging when we feel undervalued or replaceable. Consider exploring other job opportunities that align better with your values and provide a more supportive work environment. In the meantime, try setting boundaries and finding ways to take care of yourself outside of work to maintain a sense of balance.

Regarding your pet, while it may be difficult, it might be helpful to evaluate whether keeping them is truly benefiting both you and the animal. If keeping your pet is no longer tenable, consider finding them a new home where they can receive the care and attention they need.

Regarding your sibling and their legal obligations, have you tried communicating openly with them about how their actions are impacting you? Clear and honest communication can often lead to resolving conflicts and misunderstandings. If necessary, consider seeking mediation or legal advice for guidance on enforcing the fulfilment of legal obligations.

In terms of your counseling sessions with your spouse, actively listening to their wants and needs doesn't mean disregarding your own. Remember that healthy relationships involve mutual respect and understanding. Practice assertiveness and express your own wants and needs using "I" statements to avoid sounding accusatory. Seek couples therapy if needed, as a therapist can facilitate productive conversations and help both of you understand each other's perspectives.

Lastly, regarding feeling like an invisible tool, remember that you deserve to be seen and valued as an individual. Consider engaging in self-care activities that bring you joy and fulfillment. Explore hobbies, spend time with supportive friends or loved ones, or seek personal therapy to focus on your own well-being.

Remember, these suggestions are general and may not address all aspects of your situation. It can be beneficial to consult with a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and support tailored to your specific needs.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been through a lot, and I'm glad you reached out for support. It's completely understandable that after wanting love and companionship for so long, it might feel overwhelming or uncertain when you actually have it. It's also common to question the purpose of life and experience a lack of motivation and dreams.

One thing that can help is exploring your values and interests. What activities or hobbies bring you joy or a sense of accomplishment? Engaging in these activities can provide a sense of purpose and fulfillment. Additionally, setting small, achievable goals can be helpful. These goals can be as simple as completing a creative project, learning something new, or spending quality time with loved ones. By accomplishing these goals, you may find an increase in motivation and satisfaction.

Another strategy is practicing self-care. This involves taking care of your physical, emotional, and mental well-being. Make sure you're getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, and engaging in regular exercise. Exploring relaxation techniques such as deep breathing exercises, mindfulness, or meditation can also promote a positive mindset and reduce stress.
